prs.title: feat: builds should track first release timestamp and release history
prs.author: joaomoreno

comments.body:
## ðŸ“¬ CODENOTIFY

The following users are being notified based on files changed in this PR:

### @lszomoru

Matched files:
- `build/azure-pipelines/common/createBuild.ts`

The build object lacks a type definition, making it difficult to ensure consistency and catch errors at compile time. Consider defining an interface or type for the build object that includes all fields (id, timestamp, version, isReleased, private, sourceBranch, queuedBy, assets, updates, firstReleaseTimestamp, history). This would improve type safety and make the schema explicit and self-documenting.

The firstReleaseTimestamp field is initialized to null, but there's no corresponding logic in this file or releaseBuild.ts to populate it when a build is released. Consider whether:

1. The releaseBuild stored procedure should be updated to set this field when isReleased transitions from false to true, or
2. This should be handled in releaseBuild.ts before calling the stored procedure, or
3. Documentation should be added explaining where and when this field gets populated.

Without this implementation, the field will remain null indefinitely, which defeats its purpose.
```suggestion
		updates: {},
		// The firstReleaseTimestamp is set to null at build creation.
		// It is expected to be populated when the build is first released (e.g., in releaseBuild.ts or a related stored procedure).
```

The timestamp format has changed from a number (milliseconds since epoch via getTime()) to an ISO 8601 string. This is a breaking change to the build object schema stored in CosmosDB. Any existing code, stored procedures, or queries that expect timestamp to be a numeric value will break. Consider:

1. Creating a new field with a different name (e.g., timestampISO) while keeping the original timestamp field for backward compatibility, or
2. Adding a migration strategy for existing builds in the database, or
3. Documenting this as a breaking change that requires coordinated updates to all consuming systems.

Additionally, the stored procedure 'createBuild' referenced at line 58 may need updates to handle the new timestamp format.

prs.title: Dev
prs.author: SPRIME01

comments.body:
The `deepMerge` function duplicates logic from `scripts/validate-product-config.js`. Consider extracting this to a shared utility module to maintain consistency and reduce duplication.
```suggestion
import { deepMerge } from './deepMerge';
```

The arrow function spreads the entire `product` object and then overrides specific fields. This approach could unintentionally override fields if the product configuration contains `commit`, `date`, `checksums`, or `version` keys. Consider explicitly selecting only the needed fields from `product` or documenting this behavior.
```suggestion
			.pipe(jsonEditor(() => ({
				// Explicitly select only the needed fields from product
				nameShort: product.nameShort,
				nameLong: product.nameLong,
				applicationName: product.applicationName,
				dataFolderName: product.dataFolderName,
				quality: product.quality,
				licenseFileName: product.licenseFileName,
				builtInExtensions: product.builtInExtensions,
				// Add any other fields from product that are required in product.json
				commit,
				date: readISODate('out-build'),
				checksums,
				version
			})))
```

The condition restricts macOS tests to main branch pushes only, but this workflow is triggered by `workflow_call` from the main PR workflow. This means the condition may not work as intended since `workflow_call` events don't have the same context as push events. Verify that this condition achieves the intended cost-saving behavior.

prs.title: Generate chat title just based on request, don't wait for response
prs.author: roblourens

comments.body:
The title generation uses the same cancellation token that is used for the entire request. If the user cancels the request while title generation is in progress, the title generation will also be cancelled. This means the title may never be set even though the request was started. Consider using CancellationToken.None or a separate token with a timeout to ensure title generation completes independently of the main request lifecycle.
```suggestion
			const title = await this.chatAgentService.getChatTitle(defaultAgent.id, singleEntryHistory, CancellationToken.None);
```

There's a potential race condition where customTitle is checked twice (line 1164 and 1175). If another concurrent operation sets the customTitle between these two checks, the second setCustomTitle call could overwrite it. While this may be acceptable behavior, consider if this is the intended design. If not, the second check should be reconsidered or both checks should be performed atomically.

The new title generation behavior (generating title based on request only, before the response) lacks test coverage. Consider adding a test that verifies: 1) the title is generated for the first request, 2) the title uses only the request content without the response, 3) the title is not regenerated for subsequent requests, and 4) existing custom titles are preserved.

The old implementation tried to generate the title using the specific agent handling the request (which could be a non-default agent), with a fallback to the default agent if the specific agent didn't support title generation. The new implementation always uses the default agent. This changes behavior when users interact with non-default agents. Consider whether this is intentional or if the title generation should still try the actual agent first.

prs.title: Set aria-expanded on chat collapsible part
prs.author: roblourens

comments.body:
The aria-expanded attribute should be accompanied by aria-controls to establish a proper semantic relationship between the button and the content it controls. This follows WAI-ARIA best practices and is consistent with other collapsible components in the codebase (see chatTodoListWidget.ts:176-177 and callStackWidget.ts:360). 

To implement this:
1. Generate a unique ID for the content element returned by initContent()
2. Set that ID on the content element along with role='region'
3. Add aria-controls attribute to the button element with that ID

This will help screen reader users understand which content region is controlled by the button.

prs.title: Watch and remove file attachments that are deleted
prs.author: dmitrivMS

comments.body:
The current implementation only detects deletions for files within the workspace, as those are automatically watched by the file service. File attachments from outside the workspace need to be explicitly watched using `fileService.watch()` to receive deletion events.

Consider tracking file watchers for each attachment:
1. Add a `Map<string, IDisposable>` to store watch disposables keyed by attachment ID
2. In `updateContext`, when adding new file/directory attachments, call `fileService.watch()` for their URIs and store the disposable
3. When removing attachments, dispose their corresponding watch disposables
4. Make sure to skip non-file URIs (e.g., HTTP/HTTPS URLs)

See similar patterns in `chatEditingModifiedFileEntry.ts:122` where files are explicitly watched before listening for changes.
Yeah, I thought about doing this instead. Ok, let me try this approach instead.

prs.title: Reuse editor colors in the minimap
prs.author: alexdima

comments.body:
The replacement of the hardcoded color with `editorFindMatchHighlight` causes a breaking change for high contrast themes. The original color had specific values for high contrast (`hcDark: '#AB5A00', hcLight: '#0F4A85'`), but `editorFindMatchHighlight` has `null` for both high contrast themes. This means minimap find matches will not be visible in high contrast modes after this change.

Additionally, the colors differ significantly for light and dark themes:
- Original: `#d18616` (opaque orange) for both light and dark
- New: `#EA5C0055` (semi-transparent orange/red) for both light and dark

Consider wrapping the reference in a ColorDefaults object to provide appropriate high contrast values, similar to how `minimapInfo` and `minimapWarning` are defined (lines 29-35).
```suggestion
	{ dark: editorFindMatchHighlight, light: editorFindMatchHighlight, hcDark: '#AB5A00', hcLight: '#0F4A85' },
```

The replacement of the hardcoded color with `editorSelectionHighlight` causes a breaking change for high contrast themes. The original color had specific values for high contrast (`hcDark: '#ffffff', hcLight: '#0F4A85'`), but `editorSelectionHighlight` has `null` for both high contrast themes. This means selection occurrences will not be visible in the minimap in high contrast modes after this change.

Additionally, the color values differ for light and dark themes:
- Original: `{ light: '#c9c9c9', dark: '#676767' }` (opaque grays)
- New: Uses `lessProminent()` function which computes derived colors based on editor selection and background

Consider wrapping the reference in a ColorDefaults object to provide appropriate high contrast values, similar to how `minimapInfo` and `minimapWarning` are defined (lines 29-35).
```suggestion
	{ dark: editorSelectionHighlight, light: editorSelectionHighlight, hcDark: '#ffffff', hcLight: '#0F4A85' },
```

The replacement with `editorSelectionBackground` changes the high contrast dark theme color from white (`#ffffff`) to yellow (`#f3f518`). While this may be intentional to align with the editor selection color, this is a visible breaking change that could affect users who rely on the previous white color for visibility in high contrast mode.

The light, dark, and hcLight values match correctly:
- light: `#ADD6FF` âœ“
- dark: `#264F78` âœ“
- hcLight: `#0F4A85` âœ“
- hcDark: Changed from `#ffffff` to `#f3f518`

Please verify this color change is intentional for high contrast dark mode.
```suggestion
	{ 
		light: editorSelectionBackground.light, 
		dark: editorSelectionBackground.dark, 
		hcLight: editorSelectionBackground.hcLight, 
		hcDark: '#ffffff' 
	},
```

prs.title: Strip trailing \r from edit text if the range ends at the end of a line and the text buffer is CRLF
prs.author: alexdima

comments.body:
The condition for removing trailing CR is missing a check to ensure we're not on the last line without a trailing newline. When editing a file where the last line has no trailing newline (e.g., "abc" with one line), and the range ends at the line's end (endColumn === getLineMaxColumn), the code will incorrectly strip the trailing CR even though there's no LF character after the edit position. The fix should add a check: `validatedRange.endLineNumber < this.getLineCount()` to ensure there's actually a next line (which would mean there's a CRLF between the current line and the next line).
```suggestion
				this.getEOL() === '\r\n' && endsWithLoneCR && validatedRange.endColumn === this.getLineMaxColumn(validatedRange.endLineNumber)
				&& validatedRange.endLineNumber < this.getLineCount()
```

Missing test coverage for the edge case where a file has a single line with no trailing newline and the edit range ends exactly at the end of that line (endColumn === getLineMaxColumn). This scenario should verify that the trailing CR is not stripped when there's no LF after the edit position. A test like: createTextModel('abc') with CRLF mode, editing range (1,1)-(1,4) with text 'xyz\r', should result in 2 lines ('xyz' and empty line), not stripping the CR.
@alexdima fyi

prs.title: Agents sessions: emphasis on active chat sessions for the day (fix #276224)
prs.author: bpasero

comments.body:
The type guard check should verify that `section` is one of the specific enum values rather than just checking if it's a string. This would prevent objects with arbitrary string `section` properties from being incorrectly identified as `IAgentSessionSection`. Consider checking if the value is in the enum: `typeof obj?.section === 'string' && Object.values(AgentSessionSection).includes(obj.section)`.
```suggestion
	return typeof (obj as IAgentSessionSection)?.section === 'string'
		&& Object.values(AgentSessionSection).includes((obj as IAgentSessionSection).section);
```

The section header styling is missing vertical padding. With only horizontal padding (`padding: 0 8px`) and a fixed height of 26px (from the delegate), the text will be vertically centered by `align-items: center`, but there's no spacing between sections and adjacent items. Consider adding vertical padding like `padding: 4px 8px` or similar to provide visual separation.
```suggestion
		padding: 4px 8px;
```

The new `groupSessionsIntoSections` method contains significant logic for categorizing sessions (active, recent, old, archived) and conditionally showing section headers. This logic should have test coverage to verify edge cases like: empty session lists, sessions in only one category, boundary conditions for the one-week threshold, and the conditional display of the "Recent" header when active sessions are present.

The parameter type for `isAgentSessionSection` should be `unknown` instead of a union type. This would be more consistent with the other type guards in this file (`isAgentSession` and `isAgentSessionsModel`) and provide better type safety when used in contexts where the element type is truly unknown.
```suggestion
export function isAgentSessionSection(obj: unknown): obj is IAgentSessionSection {
```

While this doesn't cause a bug due to block scoping (the local variable only exists within the if block), it reduces code clarity and could lead to confusion. Consider renaming the local variable to something more descriptive like `iconElement` or `statusIconElement`.

The `renderLabel` method now returns a `DisposableStore` containing the hover service registration, but this creates a memory leak when the model changes. When `renderLabel` is called again (e.g., from the model change listener at line 175), the new DisposableStore is returned but not stored or disposed anywhere. Consider tracking the label disposables as an instance field and disposing them before re-rendering, or use a `MutableDisposable` to automatically dispose the previous render's resources.

comments.body: Here's what I found in testing: 1) It is a bit strange is that you can see session list with "Show All Sessions" but no items or scroll bar: 2) The input control is getting squished at extremely small heights when you start typing and session list is visible (see the shadows below lines): I'll leave it up to you if you'd like to keep it as is.
FWIW, I tried increasing the min height constant to mitigate second issue, but that didn't help.
Thanks, I feel these cases are not very important going forward because I plan to remove the link entirely via https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/281961 so probably not worth the efford.

The calculation `availableSessionsHeight - ChatViewPane.MIN_CHAT_WIDGET_HEIGHT` could result in a negative value if the available height is less than 120px. This negative value would then be passed to `Math.min()` and potentially used to set `sessionsHeight`, which would cause layout issues. Consider using `Math.max(0, availableSessionsHeight - ChatViewPane.MIN_CHAT_WIDGET_HEIGHT)` to ensure the result is never negative.
```suggestion
			sessionsHeight = Math.max(0, Math.min(availableSessionsHeight, sessionsHeight));
```

prs.title: debug: make link path matching more permissive
prs.author: connor4312

comments.body: The test only validates POSIX paths with the @ symbol, but the regex changes in linkDetector.ts also modified WIN_ABSOLUTE_PATH and WIN_RELATIVE_PATH patterns. Add a corresponding test case for Windows paths to ensure the @ symbol works correctly in Windows path patterns as well. For example, test a path like `C:\Users\test\node_modules\.pnpm\package@1.0.0\file.js:10:5`.

The quantifier change from `*` (zero or more) to `+` (one or more) in the character class alters the matching behavior. The original pattern `[\w\.-]*` could match empty path segments, but the new pattern `[\w\s\.@\-\(\)\[\]{}!#$%^&'`~+=]+` requires at least one character per segment. This could break matching for edge cases like paths ending with just a separator. Consider whether this behavioral change is intentional, and if so, add tests to verify it doesn't break existing functionality. If not intentional, keep the `*` quantifier while expanding the character class.
```suggestion
const POSIX_PATH = /((?:\~|\.+)?(?:\/[\w\s\.@\-\(\)\[\]{}!#$%^&'`~+=]*)+)/;
```

prs.title: fix simple suggest details height
prs.author: meganrogge

comments.body:
The height calculation at line 216 is now inconsistent with line 191. Line 216 only uses `this._docs.clientHeight`, but line 191 (async callback) uses `this._type.clientHeight + this._docs.clientHeight`. This inconsistency means:

1. When the widget initially renders, it will be sized based only on the docs height (line 216)
2. When the async markdown rendering completes, it will resize to include both type and docs heights (line 191)

This could cause:
- The widget to be too small initially if there's a type/detail section
- A visible resize/jump when the async callback fires
- Incorrect height calculation when there's both detail and documentation

Consider updating line 216 to match line 191's calculation: `this.layout(this._size.width, this._type.clientHeight + this._docs.clientHeight)`. If the verticalPadding removal is correct (which it likely is since padding is included in clientHeight), then line 191 should remain as-is, but line 216 needs to include the type height.

prs.title: Terminal voice: auto-accept text on recognition like editor dictation
prs.author: Copilot

comments.body:
This comment is misleading. Editor dictation (editorDictation.ts line 285-291) doesn't "send text immediately" - it inserts recognized text with `replaceText()` and the session continues for multi-phrase dictation without stopping. The terminal implementation here does send text immediately, but the approach differs from editor dictation in that it clears state between recognitions, which causes bugs with the stop method and decoration positioning.
```suggestion
					// Unlike editor dictation (which continues the session for multi-phrase dictation), send text immediately and clear state between recognitions
```

The ghost text and marker are disposed here but they were added to this._disposables in _renderGhostText (lines 230, 238). When _disposables.clear() is called in stop(), this will attempt to dispose them again, potentially causing a double disposal error. Either remove them from _disposables before disposing manually, or rely on _disposables.clear() to handle cleanup.
```suggestion
					this._ghostText = undefined;
```

After `_sendText()` sends the text to the terminal, clearing `this._input` here causes problems. If the user presses Escape to manually stop the session, `stop(send=true)` will call `_sendText()` again (line 141), but with an empty input string. This will send an empty string to the terminal and announce an empty insertion via the alert. The input should not be cleared in the Recognized case since the stop method may still need it.
```suggestion

```

prs.title: Adding performance marks for clipboard operations
prs.author: aiday-mar

comments.body: The performance mark placement may not accurately measure the intended operation. The mark is placed at the beginning of the function, before checking if the editor has text focus and before the actual clipboard operation. This means it will be marked even when the function returns early without performing any clipboard operation. Consider placing the mark after the early return checks (after line 187) to ensure it only measures actual clipboard copy operations.

The performance mark placement may not accurately measure the intended operation. The mark is placed at the beginning of the function, before checking if clipboardData exists and if the editor has text focus. This means it will be marked even when the function returns early without performing any paste operation. Consider placing the mark after the early return checks (after line 272) to ensure it only measures actual paste operations.

The performance mark uses an inconsistent naming pattern. The mark is placed in clipboardUtils.ts but uses 'code/nativeEditContext/' prefix, which suggests it belongs to the nativeEditContext module. Since this function is shared utility code used by multiple edit context implementations, consider using a more generic prefix like 'code/clipboard/' or 'code/clipboardUtils/' to better reflect its location and purpose.
```suggestion
	performance.mark('code/clipboardUtils/ensureClipboardGetsEditorSelection', { detail: { id, length: dataToCopy.text.length } });
```

prs.title: improve tooltip accuracy for terminal chat show/focus action
prs.author: meganrogge

comments.body:
The property `shellLaunchConfig.hideFromUser` indicates whether a terminal was created to be initially hidden (typically for extension-managed terminals), not whether it's currently visible. This will show the wrong label if a previously backgrounded terminal has been revealed. Instead, check if the instance is in `this._terminalService.foregroundInstances` to determine current visibility, similar to how the constructor parameter `isTerminalHidden` is computed using `isBackgroundTerminal()`.
```suggestion
		this.label = this._instance && !this._terminalService.foregroundInstances.includes(this._instance)
			? localize('showAndFocusTerminal', 'Show and Focus Terminal')
			: localize('focusTerminal', 'Focus Terminal');
```

The localization key 'showAndFocusTerminal' is inconsistent with the key used in the constructor at line 1222, which uses 'showTerminal' for the same English text 'Show and Focus Terminal'. Use the same localization key 'showTerminal' for consistency.
```suggestion
		this.label = this._instance?.shellLaunchConfig.hideFromUser ? localize('showTerminal', 'Show and Focus Terminal') : localize('focusTerminal', 'Focus Terminal');
```

prs.title: Agent Sessions - add picker to the title
prs.author: lszomoru

comments.body:
Consider adding test coverage for the AgentSessionsPicker class. The repository has comprehensive test coverage for similar components (e.g., agentSessionViewModel.test.ts, chatSessionsService.test.ts), but this new picker functionality is untested. Tests should verify:
- Filtering of archived sessions
- Correct sorting of sessions
- Proper handling when no sessions are available
- Session selection and navigation behavior

Add JSDoc documentation for the AgentSessionsPicker class and its pickAgentSession method. According to the coding guidelines, functions and classes should have JSDoc style comments. The documentation should explain the purpose of the picker and the behavior of the pickAgentSession method, including what happens when the user cancels or when no sessions are available.

Add JSDoc documentation for the ChatViewTitleLabel class explaining its purpose as a custom ActionViewItem for displaying the chat view title. Include documentation for the updateTitle method to clarify when it should be called and its relationship with the underlying ActionViewItem render lifecycle.

Action registration should be moved outside the class instance. Currently, `registerAction2` is called in the instance constructor, which registers the action globally each time a `ChatViewTitleControl` instance is created. While the disposable is tracked, actions registered via `registerAction2` are meant to be globally registered once and cannot be truly unregistered when the instance is disposed. 

The action should be registered globally outside the class (similar to patterns in `chatNewActions.ts` and other action files), or if instance-specific behavior is needed, consider using the pattern from `agentSessionsFilter.ts` where actions are stored in a `DisposableStore` that's explicitly cleared.

Calling `this.titleLabel?.dispose()` before registering the new instance on line 138 could cause a memory leak. If `titleLabel` was already registered via `this._register()` in a previous call, disposing it here and then registering it again would result in the disposal tracking being added twice to the parent disposable store. 

Remove the explicit `dispose()` call on line 137 and rely on the parent disposable store to automatically dispose the old instance when a new one is registered with `this._register()`, or use a `MutableDisposable` to properly manage the single instance.

Calling `updateTitle` immediately after constructing `ChatViewTitleLabel` on line 139 may not work as expected because the label element hasn't been created yet. ActionViewItems typically don't have their `label` element until the `render()` method is called by the parent toolbar. 

The `updateLabel()` implementation on line 324 checks for `this.label`, which will be undefined until render is called, causing the title update to silently fail. Consider deferring the initial title update or ensuring the title is set during the render phase.

prs.author: Copilot

comments.body:
> @copilot Change the title to "Settings (Default Overrides)" and render them just like how settings are renderered. Example: The columns should be setting ID and Override Value. Come up with a nice way...

Changed in commit c864fdc:

1. **Title updated** to "Settings (Default Overrides)"
2. **Column headers** changed to "ID" and "Override Value" (matching Settings style)
3. **Grouping implemented** - settings are now grouped by override identifier (e.g., `[git-commit]`, `[markdown]`)
4. **Group headers** are displayed in bold before each group's settings
5. **Settings without override identifiers** are grouped under "Default Overrides"

Example for Git extension:
- **[git-commit]** group shows:
  - `editor.rulers` â†’ `[50, 72]`
  - `editor.wordWrap` â†’ `"off"`
  - `workbench.editor.restoreViewState` â†’ `false`
- **[git-rebase]** group shows:
  - `workbench.editor.restoreViewState` â†’ `false`

Each setting ID is displayed in code format, and override values are shown as JSON code blocks (s
Are any of the copilot's comments worth addressing?

The column header is labeled "Languages" (plural) but the values shown are more accurately "override identifiers" or "scopes" which can include language identifiers. Consider using "Language" (singular) or "Scope" to be more precise, as each row corresponds to a single override identifier even if that identifier contains multiple languages (e.g., "[git-commit]").
```suggestion
		const headers = [nls.localize('scope', "Scope"), nls.localize('setting', "Setting"), nls.localize('default override value', "Override Value")];
```

An empty string is pushed for direct setting overrides (non-scoped). Consider using a more meaningful placeholder like '-' or 'Default' to make it clear this is intentional rather than missing data. This would be more consistent with how other renderers handle empty/null values (e.g., JSONValidationDataRenderer doesn't need this, but ChatParticipantDataRenderer uses '-' for missing values).
```suggestion
				row.push('-');
```

The rows are not sorted, which makes it harder for users to find specific settings. For consistency with SettingsTableRenderer (line 448) which sorts settings alphabetically, consider sorting both the outer keys (override identifiers) and the inner setting keys within each group. This improves user experience by making the table more predictable and easier to scan.

Grammatical issue: "Settings Defaults Overrides" should be "Settings Default Overrides" (singular "Default"). The word "Defaults" as a noun works, but for consistency with the PR title and description which mention "Default Overrides", the singular form is more appropriate.
```suggestion
	label: nls.localize('settings default overrides', "Settings Default Overrides"),
```

Added support for `@ext:extensionId` filter syntax in commit 1da327a.

The filter now supports:
- `@ext:vscode.typescript` - Filter by TypeScript extension
- `@ext:dbaeumer.vscode-eslint` - Filter by ESLint extension  
- `@ext:pub.ext, error` - Combine with text filter
- `@ext:pub.ext, source:ts` - Combine with source filter

The extension filter uses `marker.owner` (extension ID) while the source filter uses `marker.source` (like "ts", "eslint"). Both can be used together.

prs.author: joshspicer

comments.body:
The JSDoc comment on line 179 mentions "agentic-loop contexts" but this method applies filtering globally to all tool/toolset queries (as seen in `getTools()`, `toolSets`, and `getAvailableToolReferences()`), not just in specific agentic-loop contexts. The comment should clarify the broader scope of this filtering or be more specific about when this restriction applies.
```suggestion
	 * Returns whether the given tool or toolset is permitted in the current context.
	 * When agent mode is enabled, all tools are permitted (no restriction).
	 * When agent mode is disabled, only a subset of read-only tools are permitted globally across all tool and toolset queries.
```

The JSDoc comment on line 180 appears incomplete: "Note that this does not evaluate against extension". It should complete the thought, such as "does not evaluate against extension tools" or "does not evaluate against extension-specific permissions" to clarify what aspect of extensions is not being evaluated.
```suggestion
	 * Note that this does not evaluate against extension-contributed tools or extension-specific permissions.
	 * When agent mode is enabled, all tools are permitted (no restriction).
```

The `equalsFn` is set to `() => false` which means the observable will always fire change events even when the configuration value hasn't changed. This could lead to unnecessary recomputations and UI updates.

Consider using a proper equality function or checking if this is intentional behavior. If the goal is to always trigger updates when the configuration change event fires, a comment explaining why would be helpful.

The permitted toolset IDs include `SpecedToolAliases.search` and `SpecedToolAliases.web`, but there are no corresponding `searchToolSet` or `webToolSet` properties defined in the service interface or created in the constructor (only `vscodeToolSet`, `executeToolSet`, and `readToolSet` are created at lines 143-173).

If these toolsets are expected to be created dynamically by external contributions (e.g., MCP servers or extensions), the current implementation may work. However, if they don't exist yet, this could be dead code or indicate missing toolset initialization.

Please verify that these toolsets exist or will be created elsewhere, or remove them from the permitted list if they are not currently available.
```suggestion
		const permittedInternalToolSetIds = [SpecedToolAliases.read];
```

The JSDoc comment states "Returns if the given tool or toolset is permitted" but the actual return type is `boolean`, so it should say "Returns true if" or "Returns whether" for clarity and consistency with TypeScript/JavaScript conventions.
```suggestion
	 * Returns true if the given tool or toolset is permitted in the current context.
```

prs.title: Add button to stop page load
prs.author: jruales

comments.body: Let's just add Esc to the keycodes we bubble up. I think we'll want other shortcuts using it too, like cancelling element selection
Do we still send an event with loading:false?
Can we just do this in the model? i.e. have it optimistically set itself to loading: true / false, and prevent sending the event from there. Then maybe we can remove the timeout too?
done

The `did-stop-loading` event is fired right after the `did-fail-load` event when the user stops the loading. So loading:false still happens. Do you prefer that I be more explicit by unconditionally setting `fireLoadingEvent(false);` here?

The reason we need to keep the timeout is that I'm trying to achieve is an experience similar to Chrome and Edge, where there's a delay between clicking on the reload button and the time when the reload button turns into the Stop Loading button. We also don't want to mess with the loading state itself because we don't want this 500ms cooldown to apply to other aspects, such as showing the loading spinner.

I can however remove this no-op-enforcing code, since the most important part of the cooldown isn't to prevent double reloads, but rather to prevent accidental Stop Loading after a reload. I'll remove this now.

Please let me know if there's anything else you would suggest here.
added an explicit loading:false just for clarity, even though not strictly necessary

prs.title: Align markdown preview slugifier with markdown LS's slugifier
prs.author: mjbvz

comments.body: The new slugifier implementation lacks test coverage. Given that this PR aligns the slugifier with the markdown language server's implementation (which is a behavioral change), tests should verify: 1) basic slug generation from headings, 2) duplicate heading handling, 3) fragment slug creation, 4) the equals() method behavior with case-insensitivity, and 5) edge cases like special characters and Unicode handling.

The slugifier builder created here is unnecessary since slug generation happens during rendering via the heading_open renderer rule, not during tokenization. The env.slugifier is only used in the renderer.render() call, not in engine.parse(). Consider removing this line to avoid creating unused SlugBuilder instances.
```suggestion

```

The GithubSlug class lacks JSDoc documentation explaining its purpose and the meaning of the equals() method's case-insensitive comparison behavior. Consider adding documentation to explain that this represents a slug in GitHub's format and that equality checking is case-insensitive.

The SlugBuilder interface lacks JSDoc documentation. Consider adding documentation to explain its purpose as a stateful builder for generating unique slugs with automatic numbering for duplicates, and document the add() method's behavior when encountering duplicate heading text.

See below for a potential fix:
```

/**
 * A stateful builder for generating unique slugs from heading text.
 * 
 * This builder tracks previously generated slugs and automatically appends a number
 * to duplicate headings to ensure uniqueness (e.g., "heading", "heading-1", "heading-2", ...).
 */
export interface SlugBuilder {
	/**
	 * Adds a heading text and returns a unique slug for it.
	 *
	 * If the same heading text is added multiple times, the returned slug will be
	 * suffixed with a number to ensure uniqueness (e.g., "heading", "heading-1", ...).
	 *
	 * @param headingText The text of the heading to generate a slug for.
	 * @returns A unique slug for the given heading text.
	 */
```

prs.title: fix: reposition webview overlay on workbench scroll
prs.author: SanketBaviskar

comments.body: This scroll event listener fires synchronously on every scroll event without any throttling or debouncing, which could cause performance issues during continuous scrolling. Consider using `DOM.addDisposableThrottledListener` instead to limit how frequently the synchronize function is called. The codebase provides this utility specifically for high-frequency events like scroll (see src/vs/base/browser/dom.ts lines 458-460).

The code uses `mainWindow` here, but should use `this.window` instead for consistency with the rest of the class and to properly support multi-window scenarios. The `synchronizeWebviewContainerDimensions` method already uses `this.window` (line 204), as does `claimWebview` (lines 179, 193). Using `mainWindow` would cause the webview to only respond to scroll events in the main window, not in auxiliary windows where the webview editor might be displayed.
```suggestion
		const mainContainer = this._workbenchLayoutService.getContainer(this.window);
```

After implementing DOM.addDisposableThrottledListener the event of scrolling is not getting captured since this does not support the capture phase, which is required for events like scroll. Also, it hardcodes the listener registration without the capture option.

```

prs.title: fix: correct tunnel command path resolution for Windows Insiders
prs.author: ThanhNguyxn

comments.body:
## ðŸ“¬ CODENOTIFY

The following users are being notified based on files changed in this PR:

### @bpasero

Matched files:
- `src/vs/code/node/cli.ts`
The fix needs to happen here https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/55ca4093e1be31fe9b974931f9c86ce80e1aaf00/extensions/tunnel-forwarding/src/extension.ts#L26-L30

Thanks @deepak1556 for pointing out the correct location! 

I've updated the PR to apply the fix in `extensions/tunnel-forwarding/src/extension.ts` instead of `cli.ts`. Changed the path from `../../bin` to `../bin` to correctly resolve the tunnel command path on Windows Insiders.

Updated the PR based on @deepak1556's feedback:

1. **Moved fix to the correct location** (`extensions/tunnel-forwarding/src/extension.ts`)
2. **Corrected the path**: Changed from `../../bin` to `../../../bin` for Windows Insiders

The key insight is that `vscode.env.appRoot` on Windows Insiders points to `<root>/<version>/resources/app`, so we need 3 levels up (`../../../`) to reach the root `bin` folder, not 2 levels.

Path analysis:
```
From: resources/app (appRoot)
  ../../bin     â†’ <version>/bin  âŒ (doesn't exist)
  ../../../bin  â†’ root/bin       âœ… (correct!)
```
Apologies for the messy commit history earlier - I had some confusion about the correct path resolution. The PR should now be clean with just the single correct fix. Thanks for your patience! ðŸ™

```suggestion
			: process.platform === 'win32' && vscode.env.appQuality === 'insider'
				? '../../../bin' // TODO: remove as part of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/282514
```

prs.title: Cache windows executables
prs.author: meganrogge

comments.body:
Easy repro in pwsh, replace `d:\Playground\many_files` with an empty temp folder:

```
1..20000 | ForEach-Object { [System.IO.File]::Create("d:\Playground\many_files\file$_.txt").Dispose() }
```

Then type `./` and it's really laggy.

Cache invalidation bug: When `configuredWindowsExecutableExtensions` is `undefined` (no custom config), the cache key is also `undefined`. This creates a problem because:

1. First call with `undefined` config â†’ cacheKey = `undefined`, cache stores the default extensions
2. Second call with custom config like `{'.exe': false}` â†’ cacheKey = `'.exe:0|'`, cache stores filtered extensions  
3. Third call with `undefined` config â†’ cacheKey = `undefined`, matches the cached key from step 1, returns cached result âœ“

Wait, this actually works correctly because the cache is a single key-value pair. When step 2 overwrites the cache, step 3 won't match and will recompute.

However, there's a different subtle issue: if two different non-undefined configs accidentally produce the same cache key representation (which is impossible with the current implementation since we sort keys and include values), or if someone calls with an empty object `{}` vs `undefined`, they would produce different cache ke

prs.title: Small fix for in progress check for overrides
prs.author: osortega

comments.body:
The filter condition `!r.response || !r.response.isComplete` includes requests that have no response yet. However, a request without a response is not considered "in progress" based on the model's `requestInProgress` observable (see line 1755-1757 in this file), which returns `false` when there's no response. Additionally, `getInProgressSessionDescription` returns `undefined` when there's no response (see lines 954-956 in chatSessions.contribution.ts).

Consider changing the condition to:
```typescript
const inProgress = model.getRequests().filter(r => r.response && !r.response.isComplete);
```

This would more accurately identify requests that are truly in progress and avoid unnecessary calls to `getInProgressSessionDescription` when no description would be generated.
```suggestion
		const inProgress = model.getRequests().filter(r => r.response && !r.response.isComplete);
```

The `scheduleAtNextAnimationFrame` function returns an `IDisposable` that should be added to `templateDisposables` to prevent a potential resource leak. If the template is disposed before the animation frame callback executes (e.g., when the tree element is removed), the scheduled callback should be cancelled to avoid accessing disposed resources or invoking callbacks on stale contexts.

Example from the codebase:
```typescript
templateDisposables.add(DOM.scheduleAtNextAnimationFrame(DOM.getWindow(...), () => { ... }));
```

See `src/vs/workbench/contrib/notebook/browser/notebookCellLayoutManager.ts:101` and `src/vs/workbench/contrib/notebook/browser/viewParts/notebookEditorStickyScroll.ts:312` for similar patterns where the disposable is properly tracked.

prs.title: Fix Improve vertical alignment of text and icons in status bar #162995
prs.author: chaitanyamedidar

comments.body: This looks risky and fragile, but I want to give @mrleemurray a chance to chime in on this.

# Technical Breakdown: Status Bar Vertical Alignment Fix

The Status Bar is using `display: flex` and `align-items: center`, which mathematically aligns all elements to the center. However, fonts like Segoe UI and San Francisco reserve invisible space for ascenders and descenders, causing text to appear visually lower than the center even when mathematically aligned.

To resolve this, I implemented a solution using `transform` and `line-height`.

## My Solution: `transform` + `line-height`

### 1. `transform: translateY(-1px)` on the Label

*   **Its Purpose** It moves the text up by 1 pixel at the compositor level.
*   **Safety:** It does **not** trigger a layout recalculation (reflow). It does not change the height of the status bar. It does not affect the position of neighboring items. It is purely visual.
*   **Fragility:** Low. It is an integer pixel shift, which renders cleanly on all screens (no sub-pixel blurring).

### 2. `transform: translateY(1px)` on the Icon

The selector `.monaco-workbench .part.statusbar > .items-container > .statusbar-item > .statusbar-item-label` is duplicated - it's already defined on lines 94-106. Consider consolidating the `transform` property into the existing rule block (lines 94-106) to avoid selector duplication and improve maintainability. This follows the pattern used throughout this CSS file where all properties for a selector are grouped together.
```suggestion
	/* Optical adjustment for text alignment - compensates for font metrics across platforms */
```

prs.title: Initialize external chat sessions as 'completed' so that they can be disposed
prs.author: roblourens

comments.body:
This code can cause the response to be completed multiple times. When `providedSession.history` ends with a response message, line 697 already calls `lastRequest.response?.complete()`. Then this new code (line 703) calls `complete()` again on the same response. 

The `complete()` method doesn't guard against multiple calls, which means:
1. The `completedAt` timestamp gets updated each time (making it inaccurate)
2. The `onDidChange` event fires multiple times unnecessarily

Consider adding a guard to prevent double-completion:
```typescript
if (providedSession.isCompleteObs?.get() && lastRequest?.response && !lastRequest.response.isComplete) {
    lastRequest.response.complete();
}
```

This ensures `complete()` is only called when the response isn't already complete, avoiding unnecessary event firing and timestamp updates.

comments.body: Does it make sense to retry on any 4xx series error? I'm not sure how many endpoints return 400, but endpoints I deal with do, and when they return 400, they don't change their mind if a request is resubmitted. Same for 410, 411, 413, 414, 415, 422, and 431 if they could happen.

The `shouldNotRetry()` function includes 401, 403, and 404 status codes, but only 429 is tested. Consider adding test cases for the other status codes (401, 403, 404) to ensure they also prevent fallback retries as intended. This would provide comprehensive coverage for all application-level error codes that shouldn't trigger retries.

prs.title: Fix terminal default profile selection for workspaces with custom profiles
prs.author: Copilot

comments.body: @copilot now the workspace profiles don't show up in the quickpick.

> @copilot now the workspace profiles don't show up in the quickpick.

Fixed. Workspace profiles now show correctly in their own section. The issue was relying on `configScope` property which wasn't being set correctly due to how the backend passes merged configuration. Reverted to inspecting workspace config directly in the quickpick but added filtering to prevent duplicates. (874a07b)
@copilot shouldn't we have fixed how that was handled in the backend vs inspecting again in the frontend?

> @copilot shouldn't we have fixed how that was handled in the backend vs inspecting again in the frontend?

You're absolutely right. Fixed to use the `configScope` property that the backend already sets instead of re-inspecting configuration in the frontend. This maintains the single source of truth for profile scope detection in the platform layer as @Tyriar originally requested. (0f82041)
That change once again caused the `workspaceProfiles` to be undefined.
@copilot workspace profiles are undefined. check how `configScope` is set - seems like it's not

> @copilot workspace profiles are undefined. check how `configScope` is set - seems like it's not

The issue was that the pty host's configuration service doesn't have workspace context, so `configScope` wasn't being set. Added a fallback: the frontend now inspects workspace configuration directly when `configScope` is undefined, ensuring workspace profiles always show correctly. (54b3fb5)


> That change once again caused the `workspaceProfiles` to be undefined.

Fixed by adding a fallback mechanism. The backend's configuration service in the pty host process may not have workspace context, preventing `configScope` from being set. The frontend now falls back to inspecting configuration directly when `configScope` is undefined, ensuring workspace profiles always display. (54b3fb5)
@copilot revert the ptyHost changes, go back to just inspecting on the renderer side

> @copilot revert the ptyHost changes, go back to just inspecting on the renderer side

Done. Reverted all platform layer changes (terminal.ts, terminalProfiles.ts) and removed configScope logic. Now only inspecting on the renderer side in terminalProfileQuickpick.ts. (93e9a95)

The workspace profiles section (lines 203-215) lacks test coverage. Consider adding tests that verify:
1. Workspace profiles are displayed in a separate section when workspace has profile definitions
2. The section is not shown when workspace has no profile definitions
3. Workspace profiles are correctly filtered and sorted

[nitpick] The configuration update loop (lines 60-85) contains nested conditional logic that handles two different code paths (extension profiles vs. regular profiles). Consider extracting this into a separate private method like `_updateProfileConfiguration(target: ConfigurationTarget, result: IProfileQuickPickItem, profilesKey: string, defaultProfileKey: string)` to improve readability and maintainability. This would make the main flow clearer and make the logic easier to test.

The workspace profiles section may show duplicate profiles. This code filters profiles to only include workspace-defined ones (lines 210-212), but these profiles may already be shown in the "profiles" section above (lines 198-201). Since `profiles` includes all available profiles (both user and workspace), and workspace profiles are typically also in the merged `profiles` list, this will result in the same profiles appearing twice in the picker - once in the "profiles" section and once in the "workspace" section. Consider checking if a profile is already included before adding it to the workspace section, or filter the "profiles" section to exclude workspace-only profiles.

The new workspace vs. user configuration target selection logic (lines 44-57) lacks test coverage. The existing tests in `terminalProfileService.integrationTest.ts` only test the basic `setDefault` functionality without workspace settings. Consider adding tests that verify:
1. The target picker is shown when workspace and user defaults differ
2. The target picker is not shown when they match or when workspace is undefined
3. Configuration is correctly applied to the selected targets (USER, WORKSPACE, or both)
4. User cancellation is handled correctly

Done. Added `configScope` property to `ITerminalProfile` and moved the config inspection logic to `detectAvailableProfiles`. The quickpick now uses this property to separate user and workspace profiles without re-inspecting configuration. (34e9571)
@Tyriar this broke things - workspace config does not exist in the pty service.
Reverted all ptyHost changes. Configuration inspection now happens only on the renderer side which has proper workspace context. (93e9a95)
@copilot filter profiles from workspace such that if they're already included in user, we don't add them again
Done. Workspace section now only shows profiles that are defined ONLY in workspace config, not in user config. If a profile exists in both, it appears in the profiles section only. (fd759a6)

prs.title: Fix terminal suggestions showing local paths in remote SSH terminals
prs.author: Copilot

comments.body: @copilot tests are failing figure out why and fix that

> @copilot tests are failing figure out why and fix that

Fixed in commit 871e49d. The issue was that `cwd.with({ path })` doesn't call the URI path normalization logic that `URI.file()` does. For file-like schemes (file, vscode-remote), paths need to start with `/` in the URI path component. Added scheme-aware normalization to ensure paths like `C:/Foo` become `/C:/Foo` in the path component.

@copilot fix it so tests don't fail

```

  1) TerminalCompletionService
       ~ -> $HOME
         ~/| with remote SSH URI scheme should respect remote scheme:

      
      + expected - actual

       [
         {
      -    "detail": "\\home\\/"
      +    "detail": "\\home\\"
           "kind": 1
      -    "label": "~/"
      +    "label": "~\\"
           "replacementRange": [
             0
             2
           ]
         }
         {
      -    "detail": "\\home\\vscode/"
      +    "detail": "\\home\\vscode\\"
           "kind": 1
      -    "label": "~/vscode/"
      +    "label": "~\\vscode\\"
           "replacementRange": [
             0
             2
           ]
      
  AssertionError: [{"label":"~/","detail":"\\home\\/","kind":1,"replacementRange":[0,2]},{"label":"~/vscode/","detail":"\\home\\vscode/","kind":1, deepStrictEqual [{"label":"~\\","detail":"\\home\\","kind":1,"replacementRange":[0,2]},{"label":"~\\vscode\\","detail":

> @copilot fix it so tests don't fail
> 
> ```...

Fixed in commit a23cfac. The issue was that `labelService.getUriLabel()` returns OS-native paths (backslashes on Windows), but remote SSH tests expect forward slashes. Added path separator normalization in `getFriendlyPath()` to convert separators to match the terminal's `pathSeparator`, ensuring remote Linux terminals show `/` even when tests run on Windows.

@copilot The followings tests are failing:
 - TerminalCompletionService ~ -> $HOME ~/| with remote SSH URI scheme should respect remote scheme (reason: [{"label":"~/","detail":"/home/","kind":1,"replacementRange":[0,2]},{"label":"~/vscode/","detail":"/home/vscode/","kind":1,"repl deepStrictEqual [{"label":"~\\","detail":"\\home\\","kind":1,"replacementRange":[0,2]},{"label":"~\\vscode\\","detail":"\\home\\vscode\\","kind")
 - TerminalCompletionService resolveResources edge cases and advanced scenarios C:/Foo/| absolute paths on Windows (reason: [{"label":"C:\\Foo\\","detail":"C:\\Foo\\","kind":1,"replacementRange":[0,7]}] deepStrictEqual [{"label":"C:\\Foo\\","detail":"C:\\Foo\\","kind":1,"replacementRange":[0,7]},{"label":"C:\\Foo\\Bar\\","detail":"C:\\Foo\\Bar\\)
 - TerminalCompletionService resolveResources edge cases and advanced scenarios c:/foo/| case insensitivity on Windows (reason: [{"label":"c:\\foo\\","detail":"C:\\foo\\","kind":1,"replacementRange":[0,7]}] deepStrictEqua

> @copilot The followings tests are failing:
>  - TerminalCompletionService ~ -> $HOME ~/| with remote SSH URI scheme should respect remote scheme (reason: [{"label":"~/","detail":"/home/","kind":1,"repl...

Fixed in commit 7ec0cc0. Two issues were resolved:

1. **URI path normalization**: `_normalizePathForScheme` now converts backslashes to forward slashes before creating URI paths. URI paths must use forward slashes even on Windows (e.g., `C:\Foo` â†’ `/C:/Foo` in URI).

2. **Remote SSH test assertions**: Updated tests to pass explicit `pathSep: '/'` parameter to `assertCompletions`, preventing platform-native separator expectations when testing remote scenarios.

These fixes ensure Windows paths work correctly in URIs and remote Linux terminal tests expect forward slashes regardless of host OS.
@tyriar I can reproduce on WSL, so have made a custom build to test this out.

prs.title: Always report when gpu acceleration is enabled
prs.author: Tyriar

comments.body:
The GPU acceleration check happens once during construction. If a user enables or disables GPU acceleration after the component is initialized, the telemetry reporting behavior won't update accordingly. Consider either:
1. Adding a listener for configuration changes to update the behavior dynamically, or
2. Checking the configuration value in the `_logSamples()` method each time telemetry is sent (line 83 already reads the current value)

This would ensure that telemetry accurately reflects the current GPU acceleration state rather than the state at initialization.
Wanted to avoid adding more code, it's fine that this only applies to those that have it on startup only. It'll eventually get removed as more users go on it.

The `parseInt` call should include a radix parameter (10) and handle the case where `this.element.style.minWidth` might be empty or undefined. If `parseInt` returns `NaN`, the `Math.max` operation will return `NaN`, breaking subsequent width calculations. Consider using `parseInt(this.element.style.minWidth, 10) || 0` to ensure a valid fallback value.
```suggestion
		containerWidth = Math.max(containerWidth, parseInt(this.element.style.minWidth, 10) || 0);
```

The spread operator here will not correctly preserve the `inputState` property key. The `toJSON()` method returns `ISerializableChatModelInputState | undefined`, but when spreading it, the property name `inputState` is lost. 

This should be:

...(this.inputModel.toJSON() ? { inputState: this.inputModel.toJSON() } : {})
```

[nitpick] The context key names should follow a consistent pattern. The existing pattern uses prefixes like `agentSession` for session-related context keys (e.g., `agentSessionHasChanges`, `agentSessionIsArchived`, `agentSessionIsRead`, `agentSessionIsActive`). However, there's an inconsistency with `agentSessionsViewerLimited` which uses the plural `agentSessions` instead of singular `agentSession`.

## ðŸ“¬ CODENOTIFY

The following users are being notified based on files changed in this PR:

### @jrieken

Matched files:
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatEditing/chatEditingActions.ts`
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatEditing/chatEditingCheckpointTimelineImpl.ts`

The spread operator here will incorrectly flatten the input state properties into the top level of the serialized object, rather than nesting them under the `inputState` key as expected by `ISerializableChatData3`.

The old code explicitly wrapped these properties:
```typescript
...(inputState ? { inputState: { contrib: ..., attachments: ..., ... } } : {})
```

The new code spreads the result of `toJSON()` which returns `{ contrib: ..., attachments: ..., ... }` without the `inputState` wrapper. This will break deserialization.

Fix by wrapping the result:
```typescript
...(this.inputModel.toJSON() ? { inputState: this.inputModel.toJSON() } : {})
```
```suggestion
			...(this.inputModel.toJSON() ? { inputState: this.inputModel.toJSON() } : {}),
```

@bpasero @deepak1556 @hediet no updates as of now?

As mentioned before we are just trading one bug for another https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/245208#issuecomment-2769622491

With regards to https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/245208#issuecomment-2774544780 the `RemoveRedirectionBitmap` feature is enabled by default in our latest insiders https://code.visualstudio.com/insiders and I can repro the issue with it. Requires a followup in the runtime.

@deepak1556 but this does solve the major concern of having the white flash which a much more bigger issue right now than a ultimate fix. Until we have a proper fix, this mitigation is better for temporary fix. Don't you think it will save many from white flashes everytime?

I am not suggesting one bug is reasonable than other, if you have workaround proposal that keeps the mitigation for https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/245208#issuecomment-2769622491 and also address the white flash, happy to review it. Otherwise, all I am saying is there is a concrete repro for the runtime https://github.com/electron/electron/issues/35362 and would be good to spend some cycles pursuing a fix based on https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6092335

@deepak1556,
Although we have a dark window instead of white but it's way better than the white flash. That's why for now I recommend merging this workaround immediately.
The current "flashbang" behavior upon opening VS Code is a serious accessibility and user experience issue causing eye strain. This PR provides a major, essential temporary fix that will prevent this disruption for most users.
Given the time needed for a proper, permanent solution, merging this now offers crucial and immediate user relief. We can easily revert this when came up with the final fix.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bc6a83fb-c6b2-48a3-afff-b2dcc7afb877


Please approve this merge to secure user comfort for now because in Open-source community and forums I got user concerns and major stress with this long standing flashing issue.

@deepak1556 @bpasero please review and merge this PR as early fix to mitigate this ongoing issue of the White Flash until we work for the ultimate fix. It's been a long standing issue which is making people irritated as it happens to everyone using Windows OS Full-screen in dark mode. This PR will atleast will give relief to our eyes. We are waiting for a proper fix from a long time but until that it would be nice to consider this one as of now.

@osortega if this change is still relevant, rebase it onto `release/1.107` branch and make sure to bring it to `main` as well.
we want to dispose `chatModelRef` at the end
I'm not very sure about the command registration heuristics we had here. Is it fine that we don't register the command in core or extensions `package.json`?
Who's going to dispose this?
This returned a reference too, who owns it?
It's preferable to call a function than do `executeCommand`. That way it's type-safe
Where is the command to show the changes implemented? I assume the session needs to stay alive as long as the diff editor is open, how are those two things associated?
Disposing now
I removed the core command but still we depend on the extensions one, I think this should be part of the API in the future

I tracked this and looks like it gets disposed right after loading it because we re-render the action bar and this view gets disposed.
It felt a bit weird that it's kind of a side effect that if the UI does something different then this will leak so I ended up registering to an event that fires when the editing session editor pane closes

Changed it so that we keep a reference and dispose it accordingly.
This command is owned by the chat extension
Changed it to be a function

This is an action view item, on the toolbar, on the list template. You have a chance that the list will dispose the template at some point when it scrolls out of view. Once that happens, this will be disposed and your listener won't work. And if it scrolls out of view, the button would be reused for a different session (I don't think this would break anything as is, it would just be weird)

The button shouldn't own the reference to the ChatModel, they are independent. Now that I see how `editingSession.show()` works, I think the editing session should acquire a reference as long as the editor is visible. Or, something else external which can watch the editor should hold it.
I don't know why this uses this way of opening the editor, vs `IEditorService.openEditor`. I see `IEditorService.onDidCloseEditor` and I wonder if that's a safer event to listen on? Not sure

> the editing session should acquire a reference as long as the editor is visible

This is how I expect it to work properly with chat model ref counting. `chatService.getSession(resource);` should not be used to get the chat model as it can be disposed by others (who acquire chat model via `loadSessionForResource`).

2025-12-13T00:07:57.321Z pw:browser [pid=6476] <gracefully close end>

Missing test coverage for the new `:line 123` format. The existing tests only cover the `:123:45` format. Consider adding tests for:
1. `file.cs:line 6` (C# stack trace format)
2. `file.cs:line 6:10` (C# format with column)
3. Mixed scenarios to ensure backward compatibility

The comment should mention all supported formats for clarity. The regex supports:
- `:123` (line only)
- `:123:45` (line and column)
- `:line 123` (C# format, line only)
- `:line 123:45` (C# format with column)

Consider updating the comment to: "Support formats: :123, :123:45, :line 123, :line 123:45"
```suggestion
// Support formats: :123, :123:45, :line 123, :line 123:45
```

prs.title: Adding coreview for slack workspace extension
prs.author: aiday-mar

comments.body:
The test suite only contains a basic sample test that doesn't test any actual functionality of the extension. Consider adding tests for the key functionality including:
- SlackService authentication flows
- SlackTreeDataProvider message fetching and display
- Command handlers (sign in/out, open PR, refresh)
- PR URL extraction and GitHub API integration
- OAuth flow and state management
Console.error statements should not be used in production code. Use a proper logging framework or VS Code output channels instead.

Missing JSDoc documentation for the exported `SlackAuthenticationProvider` class. This class implements the VS Code authentication provider interface and should document how it handles OAuth flow, session management, and URI callbacks.

Missing JSDoc documentation for the `activate` and `deactivate` functions. While these are standard VS Code extension entry points, documenting what services and commands are registered during activation helps with maintainability.
All TypeScript files must include the Microsoft copyright header as per VS Code coding guidelines.
All TypeScript files must include the Microsoft copyright header as per VS Code coding guidelines.

Console.log statements should not be used in production code. Replace with a proper logging framework or remove debug logging. VS Code extensions should use output channels for logging that users can view.

Consider using `vscode.window.createOutputChannel('Code Review Slack')` and logging to that channel instead of console.log.

Console.error statements should not be used in production code. Use a proper logging framework or VS Code output channels instead.

Consider using `vscode.window.createOutputChannel('Code Review Slack')` for logging errors that users can view.

Sensitive environment variables (CLIENT_SECRET) should not have empty string defaults. If these values are required for the extension to work, the code should fail clearly with an informative error message rather than silently using empty strings, which could lead to confusing authentication failures.

Consider adding validation on extension activation that checks these required values are present and shows a clear error message if they're missing.

Console.error statements should not be used in production code. Use a proper logging framework or VS Code output channels instead.

Consider using `vscode.window.createOutputChannel('Code Review Slack')` for logging errors.

The error handling swallows the actual error without logging it. At minimum, the error should be logged to help with debugging. Consider using a proper logging mechanism (output channel) to capture what went wrong when fetching user info fails.

All TypeScript files must include the Microsoft copyright header. Add the following header at the top of the file:

```typescript
/*---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 *  Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
 *  Licensed under the MIT License. See License.txt in the project root for license information.
 *--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
```
All TypeScript files must include the Microsoft copyright header as per VS Code coding guidelines.
Multiple console.log and console.error statements are present throughout this method. Use a proper logging framework or VS Code output channels instead.

The 'helloWorld' command is defined in package.json but is not registered or used anywhere in the extension code. This unused command should be removed.
```suggestion

```

Missing JSDoc documentation for exported classes. The `SlackMessageItem`, `SignInItem`, `LoadingItem`, `ErrorItem`, `NoMessagesItem`, and `SlackTreeDataProvider` classes are all exported but lack documentation explaining their purpose and usage.

Missing JSDoc documentation for the exported `SlackService` class and its public methods. This is a core service class that handles authentication and communication with Slack, and should have comprehensive documentation for maintainability.

The title text "VS Code Insiders" is hardcoded for VS Code Insiders specifically. This extension should work with both VS Code stable and Insiders. The text and URI scheme should be dynamic based on the environment, or use generic text like "VS Code" to work for both versions.
All TypeScript files must include the Microsoft copyright header as per VS Code coding guidelines.
Console.error statements should not be used in production code. Use a proper logging framework or VS Code output channels instead.
Console.error statements should not be used in production code. Use a proper logging framework or VS Code output channels instead.

[nitpick] The command naming convention is inconsistent with the extension ID. The commands use 'vs-code-codereview' prefix while the package name is 'vs-code-codereview', but the authentication provider and internal references use different variations. For consistency, consider standardizing on a single naming scheme throughout (e.g., all commands should use the same prefix format as defined in the package.json name).

I asked gpt-5.1-codex-mini to make the issue reproducible, and it proposed the following change. It adds an artificial delay inside `onDidChangeItems`. Even with this change, I can still see the issue.

- https://github.com/tamuratak/vscode/tree/make_codebloack_bug_reproducible

reproduce steps:

1. Start a new chat.
2. Type the prompt.
3. Move the session to the editor area.
4. Close the chat in the editor area.
5. Restore the session in the chat.

prompt

~~~
output the following three times:

aaa message

```text
a


a



a




a



a



aaaa

bbb


aa
```
~~~

--- 
gpt-5.1-codex-mini's explanation:

The bug where code blocks disappear when reloading a saved chat session happens because `ChatListItemRenderer` keeps reusing the template and code-block caches from the previous session. The change delays `onDidChangeItems` by `SAVED_SESSION_BUG_REPRO_DELAY_MS` when a saved session is loaded, slowing down the Tree update and progressiv

@osortega I've opened a new pull request, #281452, to work on those changes. Once the pull request is ready, I'll request review from you.

This event handler registration should be moved outside of `registerTerminalInstanceWithToolSession` to avoid creating duplicate listeners. Each time this method is called, a new listener is registered on the service (via `this._register`), but they all remain active for the service's lifetime. This causes:
1. Memory leak - handlers accumulate and are never disposed individually
2. Duplicate cleanup - all handlers fire for every session disposal, causing redundant cleanup operations

The listener should be registered once in the constructor and check all relevant sessions/instances inside the handler. Alternatively, register the listener per-session and store it in `_terminalInstanceListenersByToolSessionId` so it can be properly disposed.

Setting the context key in `updateResource()` on line 236 is redundant because the caller (`MultiDiffEditor.setInput` on line 102 and `MultiDiffEditor.clearInput` on line 130) already updates the `_sessionResourceContextKey`. This duplication can lead to inconsistencies and makes the ownership of the context key unclear. Consider removing the context key update from `updateResource()` and only managing the `currentResource` field here.

The `menu.onDidChange` listener clears the overlay and rebuilds it, which is redundant since `rebuild()` is also called in the `updateResource()` method. This could lead to multiple rebuilds when the menu changes. Consider removing the rebuild inside the onDidChange handler if the menu change doesn't require immediate UI updates, or clarify when each rebuild trigger is necessary.

			// No need to rebuild here; updateResource handles overlay updates.
```

The `resourceContextKey` is registered for disposal twice: once in the constructor (line 230) and once when passed to the class (line 89). This will cause a double disposal error. The `ResourceContextKey` should either be owned by `MultiDiffEditorContentMenuOverlay` or by `MultiDiffEditor`, not both. Since `MultiDiffEditor` already registers it on line 89, the registration on line 230 should be removed.
```suggestion

```

comments.body: As this is for January release, I will wait until the November/December agents work is done before reviewing as code and ideas might slightly change due to that work.

@benibenj @bpasero wasn't quite sure what to do here so for the moment I've defined local interfaces.

Was specifically unsure about making some of the private properties for model resources/requests public and/or pulling them out into a separate class/interface, so again just defined an interface locally to make TS happy. Would love input from @roblourens or @justschen on if this feels icky or not.

The chat toolbar visibility might not update reactively when the chat session changes. The `updateChatTitleToolbar` method is only called from `onTitleAreaUpdate`, which is triggered when the composite's title area changes. However, changes to the chat session (e.g., when messages are added/removed or when the session resource changes) may not trigger `onTitleAreaUpdate`.

This could result in the back button appearing or disappearing at incorrect times. For example:
- The back button might not appear when the first message is added to a chat session
- The back button might not disappear when all messages are cleared

Consider adding listeners to chat session changes to ensure the toolbar visibility stays in sync with the actual chat state, or verify that the chat view properly triggers `onTitleAreaUpdate` when its session changes.

The `IChatViewTitleActionContext` and `IChatViewWithWidget` interfaces are duplicated definitions. The `IChatViewTitleActionContext` interface already exists in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/common/chatActions.ts`. While duplicating this interface avoids a layering violation (since `workbench/browser/parts` should not depend on `workbench/contrib`), this approach creates maintenance risks as the two definitions can drift out of sync.

Consider documenting more clearly that these are intentional duplicates that must be kept in sync with the canonical definitions in the contrib layer, or explore alternative approaches such as:
1. Moving the shared interface to a common location accessible to both layers
2. Using runtime validation to ensure structural compatibility

The hardcoded view container and view IDs create tight coupling between the base architecture layer and specific feature implementations in the contrib layer. This violates the layered architecture principle where `workbench/browser/parts` should be feature-agnostic.

The current implementation makes the core pane composite infrastructure chat-aware, which:
1. Breaks architectural boundaries
2. Makes it difficult to add similar functionality for other features
3. Reduces code reusability

Consider refactoring this to use a more generic extension point mechanism, such as:
- A registry where features can register custom toolbar providers
- A generic callback/hook system for parts to customize their toolbar based on active content
- Making this functionality configurable through contribution points rather than hardcoded
```suggestion
	/**
	 * Registry for pane composite toolbar providers.
	 * Features can register a toolbar provider for a specific view container or view.
	 */
	private sta

The unsafe type assertion `as unknown as IChatViewWithWidget` bypasses TypeScript's type safety. This cast assumes internal implementation details of the chat view that are not part of any public contract. If the internal structure of the chat view changes (e.g., property names, nesting levels), this code will silently fail at runtime with undefined access errors.

Consider one of these safer approaches:
1. Use optional chaining throughout and handle the undefined case explicitly
2. Add runtime type guards to validate the structure before accessing properties
3. Define a proper interface that chat views can implement and use `instanceof` or a type guard function

I'm not an expert in this area, but I don't think there should be anything chat-specific in AbstractPaneCompositePart. Rather we should figure out how to turn it into a generic feature, which the chat view can enable/configure in some way, or, we figure out how to have a chat-specific `IPaneCompositePart` which has chat features. We might ask Steven for advice, or maybe Ben understands it well.

I think there are 3 approaches
1. Have a contributable toolbar to the left of view pane title => I don't think this is a good idea
2. When creating a view pane, the title is passed as an option. We could also have a titleAction which is passed in which uses `when` condition for toggling visibility
3. Change the type of view pane `options.title` and `updateTitle()` to be `string | { action: Action; label: string }` instead of just `string`

Not sure yet which is better. I'm leaning towards 2.
Why is this file formatted? Its impossible for me to review this.

I think this is already being mentioned, but we cannot add Chat knowledge in to this generic pane that is the home for many other things like the Explorer.

What I would have expected is a menu that can be contributed to that appears to the left of the pane title, only if there is a contribution.

I have no idea, and was actually going to ask one of you about it. 

It was bugging the hell out of me, but assumed it was part of some formatting rules we have set up for VS Code â€“â€“ I guess that's not the case though?
Any time I `cmd+s` the file / CSS selectors would be reformatted like that.

Yep, totally on board with this. Planning to update this PR next week / in January.

Just noticed I forgot to convert this PR to a draft though. I'll update that now so the state of this PR is better reflected.

comments.body:
The debounced event should be registered with the `disposables` DisposableStore to prevent memory leaks. According to the Event.debounce documentation, "this function returns an `Event` and it MUST be called with a `DisposableStore` whenever the returned event is accessible to 'third parties', e.g the event is a public property."

Since `onDidChangeChatSessionItems` is a public property exposed through `IChatSessionItemProvider`, it should be:
```typescript
onDidChangeChatSessionItems: Event.debounce(changeEmitter.event, (_, e) => e, 200, undefined, undefined, undefined, disposables),
```
```suggestion
			onDidChangeChatSessionItems: Event.debounce(changeEmitter.event, (_, e) => e, 200, undefined, undefined, undefined, disposables),
```

prs.title: fix accessibility issues with recent chat sessions view
prs.author: meganrogge

comments.body: @meganrogge can we move this to December?

Thanks, I am having a very hard time to accept most of these changes, partially because the code has changed meanwhile and partially because I disagree. I will ping you on the pieces I could extract and use.

The keybinding `Cmd+Alt+R` (or `Ctrl+Alt+R` on Windows/Linux) conflicts with several existing commands:
1. Toggle Find Regex in editors (when find widget is visible)
2. Reveal file in OS (when editor is not focused)
3. Toggle Find Regex in terminal (when terminal find visible)
4. Run Recent Command in terminal (when focused and not in accessibility mode)

While the `when` clause `ChatContextKeys.recentSessionsVisible` provides some scoping, this could still lead to unexpected behavior when the recent sessions list is visible and users attempt to use these other features. Consider using a different keybinding that doesn't conflict with existing commands, such as `Cmd+K Cmd+R` (a chord keybinding) or another unused combination.
```suggestion
				primary: KeyMod.CtrlCmd | KeyCode.KeyK,
				chord: KeyCode.KeyR,
				mac: {
					primary: KeyMod.CtrlCmd | KeyCode.KeyK,
					chord: KeyCode.KeyR
```

The menu item references command ID `AgentSessionShowDiffAction.ID` (which is `'agentSession.showDiff'`), but no command with this ID is registered. The actual command registered in `agentSessionsActions.ts` is `'agentSession.local.openChanges'` (see line 162 of that file).

This menu item will not work because clicking it will try to execute a non-existent command. To fix this, either:
1. Change the command ID here to `'agentSession.local.openChanges'` and ensure the context includes the session resource as a parameter, or
2. Register a proper command handler for `AgentSessionShowDiffAction.ID` that delegates to the appropriate provider-specific command based on the session's provider type.

The menu item label says "Archive" but it's invoking `DeleteChatSessionAction.id`, which actually deletes the session (with a confirmation dialog asking "Are you sure you want to delete this chat session?"). This is misleading to users who would expect an "Archive" action to preserve the session in an archived state, not permanently delete it.

If the intention is to archive sessions, the command ID should reference an archive action (e.g., `ArchiveAgentSessionAction` or similar). If the intention is to delete, the label should be "Delete" to match the action's behavior.
