comments.body:
The `ghostTextIndex` should be read from `_currentPromptInputState` instead of `_mostRecentPromptInputState`. The current code takes the `ghostTextIndex` from `_mostRecentPromptInputState` but applies the substring operation to `_currentPromptInputState.value`. These two states may have different values and different ghost text positions, causing the substring to be applied at the wrong index.

Additionally, according to the `IPromptInputModelState` interface, `ghostTextIndex` is `-1` when there is no ghost text, so the condition should check for `-1` rather than `undefined`.

Suggested fix:
```typescript
const promptValue = this._currentPromptInputState.ghostTextIndex !== -1 ? this._currentPromptInputState.value.substring(0, this._currentPromptInputState.ghostTextIndex) : this._currentPromptInputState.value;
```
```suggestion
		const promptValue = this._currentPromptInputState.ghostTextIndex !== -1 ? this._currentPromptInputState.value.substring(0, this._currentPromptInputState.ghostT

prs.title: Add DOM extraction fallback to fetch tool
prs.author: dmitrivMS

comments.body:
The JSDoc comment should explain when this fallback method is used and what it returns. Consider adding details about:
- That this is a fallback for when accessibility tree extraction yields insufficient content
- The selector priority order used to find content
- The minimum length requirement for content to be considered valid
```suggestion
	 * Fallback method for extracting web page content when Accessibility tree extraction yields insufficient content.
	 *
	 * This method attempts to extract meaningful text content from the main DOM elements of the loaded web page.
	 * It searches for content using a prioritized list of selectors:
	 *   - 'main'
	 *   - 'article'
	 *   - '[role="main"]'
	 *   - '.main-content'
	 *   - '#main-content'
	 *   - '.article-body'
	 *   - '.post-content'
	 *   - '.entry-content'
	 *   - '.content'
	 *   - 'body'
	 * The selectors are checked in order, and the first element whose text content exceeds the minimum length
	 * requirement ({@link WebPageLoader

[nitpick] The regex pattern `/\\s+/g` uses double backslashes, which is correct for a JavaScript string template literal. However, consider whether collapsing all whitespace into single spaces is the desired behavior, as this removes line breaks and paragraph structure. This might make the extracted content harder to read compared to the accessibility tree extraction which preserves some structure.

Consider whether newlines between paragraphs or sections should be preserved for better readability.
```suggestion
							// Normalize spaces/tabs within lines, preserve newlines between paragraphs
							return content
								.replace(/[ \t]+/g, ' ')      // Collapse spaces/tabs to single space
								.replace(/\n{2,}/g, '\n\n')   // Collapse multiple newlines to double newline (paragraph break)
								.replace(/^[ \t]+|[ \t]+$/gm, '') // Trim spaces/tabs at start/end of each line
								.trim();
```

The new DOM extraction fallback behavior lacks test coverage. Consider adding tests for:
1. The fallback being triggered when accessibility tree returns content shorter than MIN_CONTENT_LENGTH
2. The `extractMainDomElementContent` method successfully extracting content
3. The fallback choosing the longer content between accessibility and DOM extraction

The existing test "handles empty accessibility tree" will now have different behavior (triggering DOM fallback), which should be verified or updated.

prs.title: Support triggering complex Chat Session Options
prs.author: DonJayamanne

comments.body:
The transformation logic here converts `IChatSessionProviderOptionItem` objects to just their IDs (strings), but the extension API expects to receive the full `ChatSessionProviderOptionItem` object (as defined in `vscode.proposed.chatSessionsProvider.d.ts` line 250). This breaks the API contract and prevents extensions from accessing the full option metadata (name, description, locked state, icon, etc.).

The `updatesToSend` should pass the full object, not just the ID. Consider removing this transformation entirely and letting the proxy serialization handle the object transfer.
```suggestion
				value: update.value,
```

Type mismatch: The parameter type includes `IChatSessionProviderOptionItem`, but the protocol definition at line 3323 expects `ChatSessionOptionUpdateDto` which only supports `string | undefined` (defined at lines 3276-3279). This inconsistency means the extension host is expecting a different type than what the main thread actually sends.

The type should match `ChatSessionOptionUpdateDto` from the protocol, or the protocol should be updated to use a new DTO type that supports the full object.
```suggestion
	async $provideHandleOptionsChange(handle: number, sessionResourceComponents: UriComponents, updates: ReadonlyArray<{ optionId: string; value: string | undefined }>, token: CancellationToken): Promise<void> {
```

comments.body: [nitpick] The event listeners registered with `.on()` should be cleaned up when the window is destroyed to prevent potential memory leaks. Unlike the `.once()` listeners above (lines 70-74) which automatically clean up after being called, these `.on()` listeners will remain registered. Consider storing references to these handlers and using `.off()` to remove them in a dispose method, or use `.once()` if they only need to fire once. Alternatively, since the window is destroyed at line 63 via `this._register(toDisposable(() => this._window.destroy()))`, the event listeners will be cleaned up automatically when the window is destroyed, but it's better practice to explicitly remove them.

The `login` event handler has an incorrect signature. According to Electron's API, the `login` event provides additional parameters: `event`, `authenticationResponseDetails`, `authInfo`, and `callback`. The event object doesn't have a `preventDefault()` method. Instead, you should call the `callback` with empty credentials to deny the login attempt:

```typescript
.on('login', (event, authenticationResponseDetails, authInfo, callback) => callback())
```
```suggestion
			.on('login', (event, authenticationResponseDetails, authInfo, callback) => callback())
```

The logic `!this.excludeToggle.checked || undefined` will always evaluate to `true` or `undefined`. When `excludeToggle.checked` is `true`, the expression becomes `false || undefined` which equals `undefined`. When it's `false`, the expression becomes `true || undefined` which equals `true`. This means `disregardExclude` will never be `false`, only `true` or `undefined`.

The intended logic should be: `!this.excludeToggle.checked` (without the `|| undefined`). This way, when excludes are enabled (checked=true), disregardExclude will be false, and when excludes are disabled (checked=false), disregardExclude will be true.

prs.title: Revert "Fix element already registered (#281000)"
prs.author: alexr00

comments.body:
This duplicate check has a race condition. The check happens after the node is created (line 866) but before it's added to the cache (line 870). If two concurrent calls to `_createAndRegisterTreeNode` with the same element ID occur (e.g., two simultaneous `reveal()` calls as tested in tree.test.ts), both could pass this check before either adds the element to `_elements`, resulting in duplicate registrations.

The original code (that was reverted) handled this scenario by checking for duplicates before creating the node and had logic to handle re-registering the same element object. Consider either:
1. Re-applying the reverted logic that properly handles concurrent registrations
2. Adding synchronization to prevent concurrent registrations of the same element
3. Checking for duplicates before creating the node to avoid the race window
```suggestion
		if (extTreeItem.id && this._elements.has(extTreeItem.id)) {
			throw new Error(localize('treeView.duplicateElement', 'Element with id {0}

Skipping this test instead of removing it suggests the tested behavior is still desired but currently broken. This test validates that concurrent `reveal()` calls for the same tree element don't throw duplicate element errors. 

Since the main code change reintroduces the race condition this test was meant to verify is fixed, consider either:
1. Removing this test entirely if the behavior is no longer supported
2. Keeping it unskipped if the duplicate element handling will be fixed differently
3. Adding a comment explaining why it's skipped and tracking the issue

			category: l10n.t('Stashes')
```

The stash ID format `refs/stash@{${stash.index}}` is inconsistent with the artifact provider's format. In `artifactProvider.ts` line 150, stashes use the ID format `stash@{${s.index}}` (without the `refs/` prefix), but here it's `refs/stash@{${stash.index}}`.

This inconsistency could cause issues when comparing or matching stash IDs between the artifact provider and history provider. Consider aligning with one format:
- Either use `stash@{${stash.index}}` (matching artifact provider)
- Or update artifact provider to use `refs/stash@{${stash.index}}`

The `refs/` prefix is typically used for Git references, but `stash@{index}` is revision syntax, making the combined format non-standard regardless.
```suggestion
			id: `stash@{${stash.index}}`,
```

The new stash functionality added in this PR lacks test coverage. The `getAndSyncStashRefs()` method and its integration with `onDidRunWriteOperation()` and `provideHistoryItemRefs()` should have unit tests to verify:
- Correct stash ref creation from Stash objects
- Proper handling of the stash-by-hash map
- Error handling when `getStashes()` fails
- Delta calculation for stash refs
- Integration with the history item references

Consider adding tests in a new file `extensions/git/src/test/historyProvider.test.ts` following the pattern used in other test files in the test directory.

The `getAndSyncStashRefs()` method is called from both `onDidRunWriteOperation()` (line 115) and `provideHistoryItemRefs()` (line 266) without synchronization. Since this method clears and rebuilds `_stashRefsByHash` map (line 609), there's a potential race condition if both methods execute concurrently. The `_stashRefsByHash` map is also read by `_resolveHistoryItemRefs()` (line 563), which could observe an incomplete or cleared map during concurrent execution.

Consider using the `@sequentialize` decorator on `getAndSyncStashRefs()` or adding a mutex to ensure thread-safe access to `_stashRefsByHash`.
I'm opting to follow the pattern in the historyProvider to maintain consistency within the file.
Implemented. stashes now defaults to _historyStashRefs.
@sequentialize was added to the method as suggested.
new sort function added with the suggested logic.

Skipping tests, as there does not seem to be an established pattern. 
FYI @lszomoru. Please let me know if this is problematic.

The PR now only includes the changes to enable the `anchor` option for the quick input widget and the adoption of this new option for the agent sessions picker. Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns. Thanks!

The expression `(this.dimension && this.dimension?.height * 0.2) ?? 200` has a logical issue. When `this.dimension` is truthy, the expression evaluates to `this.dimension.height * 0.2`, and the `?? 200` fallback never applies. The `?? 200` fallback only applies when `this.dimension` is falsy.

If the intent is to provide a fallback for when `this.dimension` is nullish OR when the calculated height is too large, the expression should be:
```typescript
listHeight = Math.min(this.dimension?.height * 0.2 ?? 200, 200);
```

However, since the result is already wrapped in `Math.min(..., 200)`, the current logic appears to be correct for the first case but confusing. Consider simplifying to:
```typescript
listHeight = this.dimension ? Math.min(this.dimension.height * 0.2, 200) : 200;
```
```suggestion
				listHeight = this.dimension ? Math.min(this.dimension.height * 0.2, 200) : 200;
```

[nitpick] The `anchor` parameter is typed as `HTMLElement | undefined` and passed directly to `quickInputService.pick`, but there's no guard to ensure it exists. While the quick input service may handle undefined anchors gracefully, it's worth considering whether the picker should handle the case where the anchor element is unavailable.

Consider adding a guard or documentation explaining the expected behavior when the anchor is undefined.
```suggestion

		// If `anchor` is undefined, the picker will use its default positioning.
```

The intersection check is comparing the absolute `top` position (which includes `viewport.top`) against `verticalAnchor.offset` (which is relative to the viewport, calculated as `anchor.top - viewport.top` on line 117). This mismatch could lead to incorrect intersection detection.

The check should use consistent coordinate systems. Either:
1. Compare absolute positions:
```typescript
if (Range.intersects({ start: top, end: top + view.height }, { start: anchor.top, end: anchor.top + anchor.height })) {
```
Or:
2. Compare relative positions:
```typescript
if (Range.intersects({ start: top - viewport.top, end: top - viewport.top + view.height }, { start: verticalAnchor.offset, end: verticalAnchor.offset + verticalAnchor.size })) {
```
```suggestion
		if (Range.intersects({ start: top - viewport.top, end: top - viewport.top + view.height }, { start: verticalAnchor.offset, end: verticalAnchor.offset + verticalAnchor.size })) {
```

Similar to the vertical case, the intersection check is comparing the absolute `left` position against `horizontalAnchor.offset` (which is already in absolute coordinates on line 139, where `offset: anchor.left`). However, unlike the vertical case, this one might be correct since `anchor.left` should already be in absolute coordinates.

Verify that `anchor.left` is indeed in the same coordinate system as `left`. If `anchor` is already in viewport-relative coordinates, this comparison may be incorrect.

The comment indicates the default is `below`, but the actual implementation uses `AnchorPosition.ABOVE` as the default. This inconsistency could confuse users of the API.

Update the comment to match the implementation:
```typescript
readonly anchorPosition?: AnchorPosition; // default: above
```

Alternatively, if `below` was the intended default (matching the original contextview behavior), change the implementation to:
```typescript
let anchorPosition = options?.anchorPosition ?? AnchorPosition.BELOW;
```
```suggestion
	readonly anchorPosition?: AnchorPosition; // default: above
```

The default `anchorPosition` was changed from `BELOW` to `ABOVE`. In the original contextview implementation (before this refactor), the default was implicitly `AnchorPosition.BELOW` (based on line 247 in contextview.ts where `anchorPosition === AnchorPosition.BELOW ? 'bottom' : 'top'` was used). Changing the default to `ABOVE` could break existing callers that rely on the default behavior.

Consider changing the default to `AnchorPosition.BELOW` to maintain backward compatibility:
```typescript
let anchorPosition = options?.anchorPosition ?? AnchorPosition.BELOW;
```
```suggestion
	let anchorPosition = options?.anchorPosition ?? AnchorPosition.BELOW;
```

[nitpick] The visibility update logic may cause issues during the layout phase. The `updateSessionsControlVisibility()` method changes the DOM (via `classList.toggle` and `setVisibility`) while being called from `layoutSessionsControl()`. This creates a circular dependency where layout triggers visibility updates which can trigger more layouts. prs.title: Extension API to notify changes to chat session options
prs.author: DonJayamanne

comments.body:
## ðŸ“¬ CODENOTIFY

The following users are being notified based on files changed in this PR:

### @jrieken

Matched files:
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/inlineChat/test/browser/inlineChatController.test.ts`

Potential infinite loop: When the extension fires `onDidChangeChatSessionOptions`, it flows through `extHostChatSessions.ts` and calls this method, which then calls `setSessionOption` for each update. However, `setSessionOption` (line 1053 in chatSessions.contribution.ts) fires the `onDidChangeSessionOptions` event, which could trigger the extension's listener again if it's subscribed to the service event.

This creates a circular event flow: extension event â†’ main thread â†’ setSessionOption â†’ service event â†’ possibly back to extension. Consider adding a guard to prevent re-entrancy or skip firing the service event when updates originate from an extension.

The name `ChatSessionOptionUpdateDto2` is unclear and uses a numeric suffix, which is an anti-pattern. This DTO differs from `ChatSessionOptionUpdateDto` only in that `value` is non-nullable.

Consider a more descriptive name that conveys the semantic difference, such as `ChatSessionOptionUpdateDtoNonNullable` or `ChatSessionOptionSetDto` to indicate this is for setting (not clearing) options.
```suggestion
export interface ChatSessionOptionSetDto {
```

Unnecessary optional chaining: The `_onDidChangeSessionOptions` emitter is initialized on line 263 and is never set to null/undefined, yet optional chaining (`?.`) is used here when firing the event. This is inconsistent and unnecessary.

Remove the optional chaining:
```typescript
this._onDidChangeSessionOptions.fire({ resource: sessionResource, updates: [{ optionId, value: typeof value === 'string' ? value : value.id }] });
```
```suggestion
			this._onDidChangeSessionOptions.fire({ resource: sessionResource, updates: [{ optionId, value: typeof value === 'string' ? value : value.id }] });
```

Inconsistent type definition: The event type's `value` property is typed as `string`, but `setSessionOption` (line 206) accepts `string | IChatSessionProviderOptionItem`. When an `IChatSessionProviderOptionItem` is passed, it gets converted to `item.id` (line 1053 in chatSessions.contribution.ts), but this conversion is an implementation detail that's not documented here.

Consider documenting that the event's `value` will always be the string ID, even when `setSessionOption` is called with an `IChatSessionProviderOptionItem`, or consider including the full type in the event for consistency.
```suggestion
	 * Fired when options for a chat session change.
	 * 
	 * Note: The `value` property in each update will always be the string ID of the option,
	 * even if `setSessionOption` is called with an `IChatSessionProviderOptionItem`.
```

Duplicate event firing: The `onDidChangeSessionOptions` event is fired twice for the same updates. It's first fired within `setSessionOption` (line 1053) for each update in the loop (line 1118-1120), and then fired again on line 1121 with all updates. This results in N+1 event firings where N is the number of updates. 

Consider removing the event firing from `setSessionOption` when called from `notifySessionOptionsChange`, or restructure to fire the event only once with all updates.

Potential bug when `existingNode.parent !== parentNode`: The existing node will be disposed (line 856) but may still be referenced in its old parent's children array. Meanwhile, the new node won't be added to the new parent's children array because `_updateNodeCache` only updates the parent it's given (line 1015-1019), and the existing node won't be found there.

For the specific concurrent reveal scenario this PR fixes, both nodes should have the same parent, so this may not be an issue in practice. However, to be safe, consider either:
1. Using `existingNode.parent` instead of `parentNode` (consistent with `_refreshNode` at line 833), or
2. Adding logic to handle parent changes properly (remove from old parent, add to new parent)
```suggestion

```

prs.author: hediet

comments.body: This test uses `ATTENTION_TIMEOUT` (5 seconds) but should use the actual timeout from the implementation which is 60 seconds (1 minute). Using a different timeout value means this test is not validating the real behavior of the service.

The comment states "Focus time is computed as accumulated 1-minute blocks where VS Code has focus and there was recent user activity" but this is not accurate. Based on the `TotalTrueTimeObservable` implementation, focus time is computed continuously (not in discrete 1-minute blocks) as the total duration where `hasUserAttention` is true. It's measured in milliseconds and accumulated continuously, not in minute-sized blocks.

The comment should be updated to: "Focus time is computed as the accumulated time where VS Code has focus and there was recent user activity (within the last minute)."
```suggestion
			comment: 'Aggregates character counts by edit source category (user typing, AI completions, NES, IDE actions, external changes) for each editing session. Sessions represent units of work and end when documents close, branches change, commits occur, or time limits are reached (5 minutes of wall-clock time, 5 minutes of focus time for visible documents, or 10 hours otherwise). Focus t

The documentation states "Focus time is computed as the number of 1-minute blocks in which the user has attention" but this is inaccurate. Based on the `TotalTrueTimeObservable` implementation, focus time is accumulated continuously in milliseconds whenever `hasUserAttention` is true, not in discrete 1-minute blocks.

The comment should be updated to: "Focus time is accumulated continuously whenever the user has attention (hasUserAttention is true)."
```suggestion
	 * Focus time is accumulated continuously whenever the user has attention (hasUserAttention is true).
	 *
	 *
```

The test is using `ATTENTION_TIMEOUT` (5 seconds) instead of the actual `USER_ATTENTION_TIMEOUT_MS` value (60 seconds / 1 minute). This test constant doesn't match the real implementation constant, which means these tests are not testing the actual behavior. The tests should either:
1. Use `ONE_MINUTE` instead of `ATTENTION_TIMEOUT` to match the real timeout value, or
2. Import and use the actual `USER_ATTENTION_TIMEOUT_MS` constant from the implementation

Using a different timeout value in tests than in production can hide timing-related bugs.

The documentation says "User has performed some activity (keyboard/mouse) within the last minute" but this is incomplete based on the implementation. According to the code and interface documentation (lines 31-37 in userAttentionService.ts), user attention requires BOTH conditions to be true:
1. VS Code has focus, AND
2. There was user activity within the last minute

The documentation should be updated to:
```typescript
/**
 * Service that tracks whether the user is actively paying attention to VS Code.
 *
 * This is determined by:
 * * VS Code window has focus, AND
 * * User has performed some activity (keyboard/mouse) within the last minute
 */
```
```suggestion
 * * VS Code window has focus, AND
```

[nitpick] The eslint disable comment uses `local/code-no-deep-import-of-internal` which is a repository-specific rule name. While this might be intentional for importing from an experimental/internal module, consider whether this import path should be restructured to avoid needing the disable comment. If this is a stable API that's being used, it should probably be exported through a public path rather than requiring an eslint disable to import from an internal experimental path.
```suggestion
import { TotalTrueTimeObservable, wasTrueRecently } from '../../../../base/common/observable.js';
```

The variable name `userAttentionService` is declared with type `UserAttentionService2` but the class is named `UserAttentionService2`. This is inconsistent. The variable should either be named `userAttentionService2` to match the type, or the type name should match the more generic variable name (which would be preferred).
```suggestion
	let userAttentionService: UserAttentionService;
```

The change from `TimeoutTimer` to `IntervalTimer` changes the semantics. `TimeoutTimer` fires once after a delay, while `IntervalTimer` fires repeatedly at a regular interval. For a 5-minute window reset, you want to fire once after 5 minutes, not repeatedly every 5 minutes. This will cause the reset signal to trigger continuously every 5 minutes rather than just once.

The original `TimeoutTimer` was correct. If you need to use `IntervalTimer`, you should add logic to cancel it after the first firing.

The comment states that `USER_ATTENTION_TIMEOUT_MS is 5 seconds`, but looking at the actual constant in `userAttentionBrowser.ts` line 22, `USER_ATTENTION_TIMEOUT_MS` is set to `60_000` milliseconds, which is 60 seconds (1 minute), not 5 seconds. This comment is misleading and should be corrected to say "1 minute" or "60 seconds".
```suggestion
	const ATTENTION_TIMEOUT = 5_000; // For tests; USER_ATTENTION_TIMEOUT_MS in implementation is 1 minute (60 seconds)
```

The old implementation passed specific options to `acceptInput`: `enableImplicitContext: true`, `isVoiceInput: false`, and `noCommandDetection: true`. The new code doesn't pass any options, which means these behaviors may differ. Specifically, `noCommandDetection` defaulting to false may allow slash commands to be interpreted, and `enableImplicitContext` defaults to true anyway. Consider whether these options should be preserved for consistency.
```suggestion
	widget.acceptInput(request.message.text, { enableImplicitContext: true, isVoiceInput: false, noCommandDetection: true });
```

Resource leak: `newModelRef` is created on line 106 but never disposed. When `openSession` is called, it internally creates another reference to the same session through `loadSessionForResource`. The original `newModelRef` should be disposed after successfully opening the widget to avoid leaking the reference. Consider disposing `newModelRef` after line 116.
```suggestion

	newModelRef.dispose();
```

@roblourens I pushed this leak on purpose because I don't know how to handle this. For this flow to work, I needed a new model but I don't really know where to put it... What is the idea for ref-counted chat models? How/where should I store them once I hand them over to the view?

The view will hold its own reference to the model, you can just dispose the reference after `openSession`. I think how it should work is that `IChatWidgetService` would also support starting new sessions in the requested target with one step, and you don't get a reference. Then we can move more of our complicated "new chat" actions on it.
I opened https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/280968 to give you a better way to do it but for now you should be able to just dispose the ref

Unused devDependency `@types/ncp` is declared but never imported or used in the codebase. This should be removed to keep dependencies clean and reduce package size.

Typo in documentation: "ran" should be "run". The correct phrase is "need to be run on" not "need to be ran on".
```suggestion
Such tests will need to be run on the corresponding target OS/virtual machine and will fail if run outside.
```

The smoketest script was changed to use `npm run start` but the test/smoke/package.json does not define a "start" script. This will cause the smoketest to fail with "Missing script: start". Either add a "start" script to test/smoke/package.json or revert this change to use the original command.

Using `.js` extensions in import statements for TypeScript files. The imports reference `.js` files but the source files are `.ts`. While this works with some TypeScript configurations that output `.js` files, it's inconsistent with the rest of the VS Code codebase which typically doesn't include file extensions in imports. Consider removing the `.js` extensions to follow the project's conventions.
```suggestion
import { setup as setupServerWebTests } from './serverWeb.test';
```

Version mismatch between `node-fetch` (v3.3.2) and `@types/node-fetch` (v2.6.13). node-fetch v3 has breaking changes including switching to ESM-only and returning web streams instead of Node.js streams. The code at line 147 in context.ts uses `.pipe()` which requires Node.js streams. Either downgrade to node-fetch v2 or update the code to handle web streams properly and use the correct types.

The `validateSignature` method uses PowerShell's `Get-AuthenticodeSignature` command but is only guarded by a platform check in the caller (line 153). If this method is called directly from another context without the platform check, it will fail on non-Windows systems. Consider adding a platform check within the method itself or documenting that this method should only be called on Windows.

The quality validation accepts 'insider' or 'stable', but VS Code typically uses 'insiders' (plural) for the insider channel. Verify that 'insider' (singular) is the correct value expected by the update service API at `https://update.code.visualstudio.com/api/versions/`.
```suggestion
		public readonly quality: 'stable' | 'insiders',
```

Missing type definition for `minimist` in dependencies. The package imports `minimist` but does not include `@types/minimist` in devDependencies, which will cause TypeScript compilation errors or require disabling type checks.
```suggestion
    "@types/tar-stream": "^3.1.4",
    "@types/minimist": "^1.2.2"
```

Missing type definition for `mocha` in dependencies. The package imports Mocha and MochaOptions but does not include `@types/mocha` in devDependencies, which will cause TypeScript compilation errors.
```suggestion
    "@types/tar-stream": "^3.1.4",
    "@types/mocha": "^10.0.0"
```

[nitpick] Inconsistent quotation marks in help text. Line 19 uses straight single quotes around 'insider' and 'stable', while the rest of the codebase and VS Code conventions use "double quotes" for user-facing strings. For consistency within the help output, consider using consistent quotation style.
```suggestion
	console.info(`  --quality, -q <quality>         The quality to test (required, "insider" or "stable")`);
```

`noImplicitAny` is set to `false`, which contradicts the `strict: true` setting and allows implicit `any` types. This goes against TypeScript best practices and the VS Code codebase convention of using proper types. Consider enabling `noImplicitAny: true` or removing this line to use the default from `strict` mode.
```suggestion

```

The type assertion `as Response & { body: NodeJS.ReadableStream }` is used because the type guard checks pass. However, the actual runtime type of `response.body` from node-fetch v3 is `ReadableStream<Uint8Array> | null`, not `NodeJS.ReadableStream`. This type assertion is incorrect and could lead to runtime errors when trying to use Node.js stream methods. Consider using proper stream handling or updating the type to match the actual node-fetch v3 API.

Calling `.read(undefined)` on an observable bypasses the reactive dependency tracking. This means the initial value is read once but won't react to changes. The subsequent `subscribeModelToDiffUpdates` call on line 1822 will handle updates, but there's a potential race condition: if `getDiffsForFilesInSession()` updates between this line and the subscription, the update could be missed. Consider moving this initial set inside the `subscribeModelToDiffUpdates` method or using a reader context instead of `undefined`.

[nitpick] Extra blank line should be removed to maintain consistency with the codebase style.
```suggestion

```

The `autorun` is registered with `this._register()` but should be added to the `disposables` store instead. The `disposables` store is tied to the model's lifecycle (line 612-615), while `this._register()` ties it to the ChatService instance lifecycle, which could lead to memory leaks if the model is disposed before the service. Use `disposables.add(autorun(...))` to match the pattern used in the if-block above (line 683).

Yes, exactly! This fix ensures that Pro/ProPlus/Business/Enterprise users see a warning in the status bar when they exceed their premium chat quota, just like Free users currently see warnings when they exceed their quotas.

**Current behavior:** Only Free tier users see quota warnings in the status bar
**New behavior:** All entitled users (Free, Pro, ProPlus, Business, Enterprise) see appropriate quota warnings

The `premiumChat` quota is already tracked in the system and displayed in the dashboard, but the status bar warning logic was missing the check for it. This change brings the status bar in line with the existing quota tracking system.

## ðŸ“¬ CODENOTIFY

The following users are being notified based on files changed in this PR:

The new `getChatSessionType` function should have JSDoc documentation explaining its purpose, parameters, and return value. This would be consistent with other exported functions in this file (like `chatSessionResourceToId` above) and would help developers understand when to use this function.

Consider adding documentation like:
```typescript
/**
 * Extracts the chat session type from a resource URI.
 * 
 * @param resource - The chat session resource URI
 * @returns The session type string. Returns `localChatSessionType` for local sessions 
 *          (vscodeChatEditor and vscodeLocalChatSession schemes), or the scheme/authority 
 *          for contributed sessions.
 */
```
```suggestion

/**
 * Extracts the chat session type from a resource URI.
 *
 * @param resource - The chat session resource URI
 * @returns The session type string. Returns `localChatSessionType` for local sessions
 *          (vscodeChatEditor and vscodeLocalChatSession schemes), or the scheme/authority
 *

There's a potential for calling `canResolveChatSession` twice for non-local sessions. In `loadSession` (line 396), we call `canResolveChatSession` without error handling, then in `updateModel` (line 197), we call `updateWidgetLockState` which also calls `canResolveChatSession` (line 466) but with error handling.

If the first call fails, it will throw and the session won't load. If it succeeds, we'll make the same call again in `updateWidgetLockState`. Consider removing the call in `loadSession` since `updateWidgetLockState` already handles this check with proper error handling.

See below for a potential fix:
```
		// Removed redundant canResolveChatSession call; error handling is done in updateWidgetLockState
```

comments.body:
The configuration description "Show the status widget in new chat sessions when quota is exceeded" doesn't accurately reflect the new SKU-based behavior. Since the setting is now an enum that selects which user type (free or anonymous) should see the widget, consider updating the description to something like "Controls which user type should see the status widget in new chat sessions when quota is exceeded" or "Select which SKU tier should display the status widget when quota limits are reached".
```suggestion
			description: nls.localize('chat.statusWidget.enabled.description', "Controls which user type should see the status widget in new chat sessions when quota is exceeded."),
```

[nitpick] Remove the extra blank line for consistency with the codebase style.
```suggestion

```

The parameter name `testSku` is misleading as it suggests this is for testing purposes. Since this is a production feature parameter that determines which SKU configuration is enabled, consider renaming it to `enabledSku` to match the variable name used in `initializeIfEnabled()` and `updateContent()`.
```suggestion
	private createWidgetContent(enabledSku: 'free' | 'anonymous'): void {
```

The button command logic in `createWidgetContent` doesn't align with the visibility logic in `updateContent`. In `createWidgetContent`, the command is determined solely by `chatEntitlementService.anonymous`, but in `updateContent`, the widget content is shown based on both `enabledSku` and entitlement state. This mismatch could lead to incorrect commands being executed. For example, if `enabledSku === 'free'` and the user is anonymous, the button might show "Upgrade" (from line 109) but execute the setup action (from line 87). Consider passing `enabledSku` to determine the correct command, similar to how `updateContent` uses it.

comments.body: @microsoft-github-policy-service agree
@sandy081 , Please review this PR.
@lszomoru , please review this PR.

> Tested locally and verified the queries are happening concurrently now.

This is good, but is the issue that https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/280336 is seeing? If fetching remote extension hangs then it will block even if you do parallelly right?

Hi @sandy081,

Thanks for testing!

You're right to question this. The root cause of #280336 is `queryLocal()` awaiting servers **sequentially**. If WSL/remote hung, it blocked everything â†’ frozen UI.

**My fix:**
1. Parallelized queries - even if remote hangs, local extensions load and UI stays responsive
2. "Install Local Extensions" now only queries local server, avoiding the hung remote server

This won't prevent individual hangs, but stops them from cascading and freezing the entire extension system. Based on #280336's symptoms (empty list, stuck UI), sequential blocking was the culprit.

Happy to add timeout handling later if needed, but this should resolve the reported issue.
Would you be open to merging this?

> The root cause of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/280336 is queryLocal() awaiting servers sequentially. If WSL/remote hung, it blocked everything â†’ frozen UI.

Have you tried this? Because UI asks extensions per server which means there will be only single request

@sandy081 

You're right to challenge this. If the UI makes separate `queryLocal()` calls per server (one for local, one for remote, etc.), then parallelizing within a single call wouldn't help.

Could you point me to where the UI requests extensions? I want to verify whether my fix addresses the actual flow or if I need to look elsewhere.

Thanks for the guidance!

Here - 
https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/9913515e4720b3d52b34ca83708ade1228c97e64/src/vs/workbench/contrib/extensions/browser/extensionsViews.ts#L336

prs.title: Engineering - add GitHub action to prevent changes to the engineering system
prs.author: lszomoru

comments.body:
The `on:` trigger is missing the required structure. It should be `on: pull_request:` (with a colon) or `on: [pull_request]` to properly define the workflow trigger. The current syntax will cause the workflow to fail to trigger.
```suggestion
on: [pull_request]
```

The workflow lacks read permissions needed for its operations. The `permissions: {}` setting denies all permissions, but the workflow needs:
1. `contents: read` to check out code and access file changes
2. `pull-requests: read` to read PR metadata

Add:
```yaml
permissions:
  contents: read
  pull-requests: read
```
```suggestion
permissions:
  contents: read
  pull-requests: read
```

Security: The shell script is vulnerable to command injection. If a filename in the PR contains special characters or shell metacharacters, it could lead to command injection when processed by `jq`. Additionally, the pattern relies on `$HOME/files.json` which may not exist if the file-changes-action fails or returns no data.

Consider using the action's outputs directly instead of reading from a file:
```yaml
run: |

The regex pattern `package\\.json$` will only match a file named exactly "package.json" at the root, but will miss nested package.json files like `extensions/*/package.json` or `build/*/package.json`. 

If the intent is to protect all package.json files in the repository, use:
```bash
if cat $HOME/files.json | jq -e 'any(test("^\\.github/workflows/|^build/|package\\.json"))' > /dev/null; then
```

Or if only the root package.json should be protected, the current pattern is correct but should be documented in comments.
```suggestion
          if cat $HOME/files.json | jq -e 'any(test("^\\.github\\/workflows\\/|^build\\/|package\\.json"))' > /dev/null; then
```

The regex pattern has inconsistent escaping. In the jq regex:
- `^\\.github\\/workflows\\/` - backslashes are escaped correctly
- `^build\\/` - forward slash is unnecessarily escaped (not needed in jq regex)
- `package\\.json$` - correctly escapes the dot

For consistency and correctness, the pattern should be:
```bash
if cat $HOME/files.json | jq -e 'any(test("^\\.github/workflows/|^build/|package\\.json$"))' > /dev/null; then
```

Forward slashes don't need escaping in jq regex patterns.
```suggestion
          if cat $HOME/files.json | jq -e 'any(test("^\\.github/workflows/|^build/|package\\.json$"))' > /dev/null; then
```

The condition checks for `github.event.pull_request.user.login == 'Copilot'`, but GitHub Copilot typically operates as `copilot-[identifier]` or similar patterns, not as a user named exactly 'Copilot'. This condition may never evaluate to true.

Consider:
1. Using a pattern match like `contains(github.event.pull_request.user.login, 'copilot')`
2. Verifying the actual username format used by GitHub Copilot in your environment
3. Using `github.actor` instead of `github.event.pull_request.user.login` if checking the PR author
```suggestion

        run: |
          echo "Copilot is not allowed to modify .github/workflows, build folder files, or package.json files."
          echo "If you need to update engineering systems, please do so manually or through authorized means."
          exit 1
      - uses: octokit/request-action@dad436

The hardcoded repository path `microsoft/vscode` should use the GitHub Actions context variable `${{ github.repository }}` instead. This makes the workflow reusable and prevents issues if it's forked or the repository is renamed:

```yaml
route: GET /repos/${{ github.repository }}/collaborators/${{ github.event.pull_request.user.login }}/permission
```
```suggestion
          route: GET /repos/${{ github.repository }}/collaborators/${{ github.event.pull_request.user.login }}/permission
```

[nitpick] Typo: "dependabot" should be "Dependabot" (capitalized) for consistency with how it appears in the actual check `dependabot[bot]` and for proper noun capitalization in logging output.
```suggestion
          echo "is Dependabot: ${{ github.event.pull_request.user.login == 'dependabot[bot]' }}"
```

Logic issue: If `steps.get_permissions` fails or returns an error (e.g., for users not in the collaborators list), `fromJson(steps.get_permissions.outputs.data).permission` will fail with a null/undefined error. This will cause the workflow to fail unexpectedly instead of properly blocking the PR.

Add error handling:
```yaml
- name: Set control output variable
  id: control
  if: ${{ steps.engineering_systems_check.outputs.engineering_systems_modified == 'true' && github.event.pull_request.user.login != 'Copilot' }}
  run: |
    PERMISSION="${{ fromJson(steps.get_permissions.outputs.data).permission }}"
    if [ -z "$PERMISSION" ]; then
      echo "Failed to get user permissions, assuming no write access"
      echo "should_run=true" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
      exit 0
    fi
    # ... rest of logic
```

The `currentToolCallLabel` is overwritten every time `appendItem` is called with a tool invocation. When multiple tool invocations exist, only the last one's `pastTenseMessage` is stored. However, line 302 checks `this.toolInvocationCount === 1`, so this should only apply when there's one tool. But if tool invocations are added sequentially and the check runs after multiple tools are added, `currentToolCallLabel` will contain the last tool's message, not the first. Consider only setting `currentToolCallLabel` when `toolInvocationCount === 1` to ensure it represents the single tool case: `if (toolInvocation?.pastTenseMessage && this.toolInvocationCount === 1) { ... }`

```

This test is too vague and doesn't actually verify the correct behavior. The comment suggests the behavior "depends on implementation" but this is a unit test that should verify specific expected behavior. Either:

1. If `update()` should process WWW-Authenticate headers regardless of status code (401 vs 403), assert that it returns `true` and updates the scopes to `['new.scope']`
2. If `update()` should only process 401 responses, assert that it returns `false` and scopes remain `['read']`

The current assertion `assert.strictEqual(typeof result, 'boolean')` is essentially meaningless - it only checks that the function returns a boolean, which is already enforced by TypeScript.

The test verifies that `update()` returns `false` when scopes are the same but in different order, but it doesn't assert what the final scopes should be. Since the function returns `false`, the scopes should remain unchanged (i.e., `['read', 'write']`). Consider adding an assertion like:
```typescript
assert.deepStrictEqual(authMetadata.scopes, ['read', 'write']);
```
This would make the test more complete and verify that scopes weren't accidentally modified.

# Response to Reviewer

Good question about URL encoding. I looked into the VS Code codebase to see how this kind of thing is typically handled.

## What I found

I searched through the existing logger creation patterns and filename sanitization in the codebase. A few things stood out:

**How logger IDs become filenames:**

In `src/vs/platform/log/common/log.ts` (lines 653-655), when you pass a string ID, it goes straight into `joinPath()`:

```typescript
protected toResource(idOrResource: string | URI): URI {
    return isString(idOrResource) ? joinPath(this.logsHome, `${idOrResource}.log`) : idOrResource;
}
```

There's no sanitization or encoding happening there. That's why we hit the Windows path error with characters like `:`, `/`, `?`.

**Existing patterns:**

Looking at 50+ logger creation calls across the codebase, they all use simple IDs like `'network'`, `'terminal'`, `'remoteagent'`. I couldn't find any examples of URLs or complex strings being used as

comments.body: The use of `const self = this;` is unnecessary in modern JavaScript/TypeScript. Arrow functions in the command handler would automatically capture `this` context. Consider using an arrow function instead of storing `this` in a variable for better code clarity and adherence to modern JavaScript conventions.

The `validateDefinitions` method is added but not called anywhere in the changes. This could indicate incomplete implementation or dead code. If this is part of a future feature, consider adding a TODO comment explaining when it will be used, or remove it if it's not needed.

The command execution returns `RenameKind` which is an enum, but `executeCommand` is typed to return `RenameKind` directly. However, the actual return value will be a string from the command handler. The call to `RenameKind.fromString(result)` on line 388 assumes `result` is a string, but TypeScript will treat it as a `RenameKind`. This type mismatch could cause runtime errors. Consider using `executeCommand<string>` instead and handling the string conversion properly.

In the command handler, when `id` doesn't match (line 282-287), a new `RenameSymbolRunnable` is created but its result is never applied. The code fetches the workspace edit but then returns immediately without applying it via `bulkEditService.apply()`. This appears to be a logic error where rename edits are silently discarded. Either remove the `return` statement on line 287, or clarify the intended behavior with a comment.
```suggestion

```

The `source` parameter passed to the `RenameSymbolRunnable` constructor is not used in the class. The parameter should either be removed if not needed, or utilized in the implementation if it was intended for future use.
```suggestion
	constructor(languageFeaturesService: ILanguageFeaturesService, textModel: ITextModel, position: Position, newName: string) {
```

The `getCount()` method is defined but appears to never be called. Consider removing this method if it's not needed, or document its intended usage if it's part of a public API that will be used in the future.
```suggestion

```

The `ShiftKeybinding` class returns `false` for both `ctrlKey`, `shiftKey`, `altKey`, and `metaKey` in the `ResolvedChord`, which is inconsistent with representing a Shift key. The `shiftKey` parameter should be `true` since this represents the Shift key.

		return [new ResolvedChord(false, true, false, false, 'Shift', 'Shift')];
```

The commented-out code `//this._secondaryElement.map((e, r) => e?.isHovered.read(r) ?? false)` is replaced with `constObservable(false)`, which means the secondary element hover state is never active. This appears to be dead code that should either be implemented or the comment removed.

				const secondaryElementHovered = this._secondaryElement.map((e, r) => e?.isHovered.read(r) ?? false);
```

```

						.executeCommand(action.alternativeAction.id, ...(action.alternativeAction.arguments || []))

prs.title: Reduce use of explicit `any` type (#274723)
prs.author: bpasero

comments.body:
The change from `let args: any = []` to `let args = []` will cause TypeScript to infer the type as `never[]`, which is incorrect since `parse()` returns `any` and can return values of various types. This will lead to type errors when assigning the result of `parse()` to `args` (lines 1324 and 1328).

Consider using `let args: unknown[] = []` or `let args: any[] = []` instead to maintain type safety while accepting values from the untyped `parse()` function.
```suggestion
			let args: any[] = [];
```

The filter logic in `getHistorySessionItems()` duplicates conditions from `shouldBeInHistory()`. Consider using `shouldBeInHistory()` here as well to maintain consistency with `getLiveSessionItems()`. However, note that `shouldBeInHistory()` expects a `ChatModel` while this operates on index entries, so you'd need to either adapt the method or create a shared helper function.

The `shouldBeInHistory()` method signature was changed from accepting `Partial<ChatModel>` to `ChatModel`, which is more type-safe. However, the method would benefit from a JSDoc comment explaining its purpose and when a session should be considered "in history" (i.e., not imported, has a valid local session ID, and is from the Chat location).
```suggestion

	/**
	 * Determines whether a chat session should be included in the session history.
	 *
	 * A session is considered "in history" if:
	 * - It is not imported (`isImported` is false)
	 * - It has a valid local session ID (as parsed from `sessionResource`)
	 * - Its initial location is the Chat location (`initialLocation === ChatAgentLocation.Chat`)
	 *
	 * @param entry The chat session model to check.
	 * @returns True if the session should be included in history; otherwise, false.
	 */
```

prs.title: fix: update mathInlineRegExp to correctly handle $(a+b)^2$
prs.author: tamuratak

comments.body:
The comment could be clearer about what patterns are blocked. Consider updating to: "opening $ not followed by `.`, `("`, or `('`" to make it explicit that both `$("` and `$('` are blocked, but `$(` followed by other characters is allowed.
```suggestion
export const mathInlineRegExp = /(?<![a-zA-Z0-9])(?<dollars>\${1,2})(?!\.|\(["'])((?:\\.|[^\\\n])*?(?:\\.|[^\\\n\$]))\k<dollars>(?![a-zA-Z0-9])/; // Non-standard: ensures opening $ is not preceded and closing $ is not followed by word/number characters. Blocks opening $ not followed by `.`, `("`, or `('` (i.e., blocks both `$("` and `$('` but allows `$(` followed by other characters).
```

```

Potential issue: Line 1424 uses `this._zone.rawValue?.hide()` to avoid forcing initialization of the Lazy zone, but line 1425 uses `this._zone.value.widget.chatWidget.setModel(undefined)` which will force initialization if the zone hasn't been created yet. This inconsistency means the zone could be unnecessarily created just to set its model to undefined. Consider using `this._zone.rawValue?.widget.chatWidget.setModel(undefined)` instead to maintain consistency with line 1424.
```suggestion
				this._zone.rawValue?.widget.chatWidget.setModel(undefined);
```

The new behavior on lines 1380-1386 that disposes empty sessions (those without requests, input text, or attachments) when switching files lacks test coverage. Given that there are existing tests for file switching behavior (e.g., "moving inline chat to another model undoes changes"), consider adding a test case that verifies empty sessions are properly disposed when switching files while non-empty sessions are preserved.

comments.body:
The validation for the `extension` property in `isILanguageModelChatSelector` is incorrect. According to the interface definition at line 222-230, `extension` is of type `ExtensionIdentifier`, which is a class (not a plain object). The current check `typeof obj.extension === 'object'` will accept any object, including plain objects that don't have the required `value` and `_lower` properties of `ExtensionIdentifier`.

Consider using `ExtensionIdentifier` instance check or a more specific validation:
```typescript
(obj.extension === undefined || obj.extension instanceof ExtensionIdentifier)
```

Alternatively, if serialization is a concern and you need to validate the shape:
```typescript
(obj.extension === undefined || (typeof obj.extension === 'object' && obj.extension !== null && typeof (obj.extension as any).value === 'string'))
```
```suggestion
		(obj.extension === undefined || obj.extension instanceof ExtensionIdentifier)
```

The condition uses a logical OR which means the model is reset if EITHER check fails. However, there's a missing configuration listener for `InlineChatConfigKeys.EnableV2`. Similar to how `ChatConfiguration.Edits2Enabled` has a listener at line 590-592 (because it affects `modelSupportedForDefaultAgent()`), there should be a listener for `InlineChatConfigKeys.EnableV2` since it affects `modelSupportedForInlineChat()`. Without this listener, when a user toggles inline chat v2, the currently selected model won't be re-validated until another event triggers `checkModelSupported()`. Consider adding a configuration listener like: `if (e.affectsConfiguration(InlineChatConfigKeys.EnableV2)) { this.checkModelSupported(); }` in the `initSelectedModel()` method alongside the existing `ChatConfiguration.Edits2Enabled` listener.

comments.body:
The `activeSuggestion` performance marker will be added multiple times to the same suggestion object if a user cycles through suggestions. For example, if a user navigates through suggestions A â†’ B â†’ C â†’ A using keyboard shortcuts (Alt+] / Alt+[), the marker will be added to suggestion A twice (once initially and once when cycling back).

This happens because the autorun triggers whenever `state.map(s => s?.inlineSuggestion)` changes, and cycling through suggestions changes the selected suggestion reference. The `InlineSuggestionsPerformance.mark()` method doesn't check for duplicate markers and simply appends each marker to the array.

Consider tracking whether the marker has already been added to prevent duplicates, or use a different approach such as `recomputeInitiallyAndOnChange` with change tracking to ensure the marker is only added when a suggestion first becomes active.

[nitpick] Reducing the diff computation timeout from 500ms to 50ms is a significant 90% reduction that could affect the quality of diff results for larger inline completions. This change may cause the diff algorithm to timeout more frequently and produce less optimal results. Consider whether 50ms is sufficient for typical use cases, or if a middle ground (e.g., 100-200ms) would provide better balance between performance and diff quality.

prs.author: hediet

comments.body:
## ðŸ“¬ CODENOTIFY

The following users are being notified based on files changed in this PR:

### @jrieken

Matched files:
- `src/vs/editor/contrib/suggest/browser/suggestInlineCompletions.ts`

Returning `undefined` from `map` and then filtering is less efficient than using `filter` before `map`. Consider restructuring to `suggestions.filter(c => !c.getSourceCompletion().doNotLog).map(c => { ... })` to avoid unnecessary object construction and improve readability.
```suggestion
					const result = suggestions
						.filter(c => !c.getSourceCompletion().doNotLog)
						.map(c => {
							const comp = c.getSourceCompletion();
							const obj = {
								insertText: comp.insertText,
								range: comp.range,
								additionalTextEdits: comp.additionalTextEdits,
								uri: comp.uri,
								command: comp.command,
								gutterMenuLinkAction: comp.gutterMenuLinkAction,
								shownCommand: comp.shownCommand,
								completeBracketPairs: comp.completeBracketPairs,
								isInlineEdit: comp.isInlineEdit,
								showInlineEditMenu: comp.showInlineEditMenu,
								showRange: comp.showRange,
								warning: comp.warning,
								hint: comp.hint,
								supportsRename: comp

The explicit property mapping duplicates the structure of `InlineCompletion` and will require manual updates if new properties are added. This creates a maintenance burden. The previous `mapDeep` approach was more maintainable. If the switch to `cloneAndChange` is necessary, consider documenting why explicit property mapping is required or using a more maintainable approach like spreading the object with property exclusion: `const { doNotLog, ...obj } = comp;`
```suggestion
						const { doNotLog, ...obj } = comp;
```

prs.title: Display diagnostics returned by Chat session history contributions
prs.author: DonJayamanne

comments.body:
The line assigns `refValue.owner` to the returned object, but `refValue` (of type `IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData`) doesn't have an `owner` property defined at this point. The `owner` property is optional in `IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData` and is not set when creating `refValue` above. This results in `owner` being `undefined`, which may not be the intended behavior.

If the owner should be set, it should be added to the `refValue` object when it's created (lines 420-425). If `undefined` is acceptable, this line can be removed as the spread operator on line 438 would already include it from spreading `...refValue`.
```suggestion

```

The manually assigned `ref.id` and `ref.name` values may not follow the same ID generation and label formatting logic used by the helper functions `IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData.id()` and `IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData.label()` (lines 172-200 in chatVariableEntries.ts). This could lead to inconsistencies when the same diagnostic is represented elsewhere in the system.

The helper function `IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData.id()` generates IDs based on `[filterUri, owner, filterSeverity, filterRange.startLineNumber, filterRange.startColumn].join(':')`, and `label()` provides special trimming logic for problem messages. Using these helpers ensures consistent identification and display of diagnostics across the application.

The code manually assigns `icon: Codicon.error` instead of using the existing constant `IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData.icon` (line 150 in chatVariableEntries.ts). While they currently have the same value, using the shared constant ensures consistency and makes it easier to maintain if the icon needs to change in the future.

Replace `icon: Codicon.error,` with `icon: IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData.icon,` or let the helper function `IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData.toEntry()` handle this.
```suggestion
				icon: IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData.icon,
```

Lines 433-436 spread properties from `refValue` which duplicates fields that are already in the returned object. The `satisfies` check ensures type compatibility, but spreading `refValue` here adds `filterRange`, `problemMessage`, `filterSeverity`, and `filterUri` to the object twice (once explicitly on lines 433-436, once via the spread).

This is redundant. Either spread `refValue` and omit the explicit field assignments, or keep the explicit assignments and omit the spread. For example:
```typescript
return {
	id: ref.id,
	name: ref.name,
	icon: Codicon.error,
	value: refValue,
	kind: 'diagnostic',
	modelDescription: ref.modelDescription,
	...refValue, // This spreads all properties including filterRange, problemMessage, etc.
} satisfies IDiagnosticVariableEntry;
```
```suggestion
				...refValue,
```

The new diagnostic reference handling logic lacks test coverage. While the repository has comprehensive test coverage for chat sessions (see `mainThreadChatSessions.test.ts`), there are no tests verifying that `ChatReferenceDiagnostic` objects are correctly converted to `IDiagnosticVariableEntry` objects.

Consider adding tests that verify:
1. Correct conversion of diagnostic references with all required fields
2. Proper handling of edge cases (empty diagnostic arrays, missing fields)
3. Consistency with `IDiagnosticVariableEntryFilterData` helper functions
4. Correct icon, id, and name generation

This is especially important given the complexity of the conversion logic and the multiple potential issues identified in this review.

prs.title: chat - tweak behaviour of `openSession`
prs.author: bpasero

comments.body: This should not be defined explicitly but be derived from `e.editorOptions` where this is set properly.
We have `IEditorService.findEditors` to help you find an existing editor, no need to iterate over groups yourself.
We maintain an editor option `revealIfOpened` to prefer revealing an opened editor if it exists, no need to manually search for it.

This is up for debate: if I am passing in an explicit target (chat view or editor), I want that to be respected because otherwise you end up with a weird interaction where sometimes it would open an editor and sometimes it would reveal in the sidebar. We want sessions from the agent sessions view to always open in the editor.

However: if you click on a session that is also live in a sidebar, you essentially end up having it opened twice, which seems to work fine, but nevertheless did not happen before. Should we detect this case and then move the session from the sidebar into the editor? I guess the same can happen if you have it open in the editor and want to open it in the sidebar.

Redundant optional chaining operator on `chatView?.widget`. Since this code is inside the `if (chatView)` block (line 107), `chatView` is guaranteed to be defined at this point. The optional chaining operator `?.` is unnecessary and should be replaced with direct property access: `chatView.widget.viewModel?.sessionResource`.
```suggestion
				const chatViewSessionResource = chatView.widget.viewModel?.sessionResource;
```

The word "explicit" is misspelled as "a explicit". It should be "an explicit" since "explicit" starts with a vowel sound.
```suggestion
		// Reveal if already open unless an explicit target is specified
```

I don't see why anyone would want to have the same chat opened twice. It doesn't work well IMO now that we have one 'input model' attached to the ChatModel.

Forcibly moving chats around from the session view seems weird, if I started a chat in the view, why can't I just continue it there?

@roblourens first of all: if you provide an API that allows me to pass in an editor group, then you should support that and not just decide to open somewhere else.

And then: the agent sessions view should never open or reveal a chat in the side bar, it would be very weird to click through sessions in the sidebar and sometimes you end up in a different view and sometimes in the editor. For a user that is very unpredictable, almost as if a file from the explorer sometimes open in the window and sometimes in a new window. Its crucial that the experience is consistent.

You may have used a sidebar chat without real intent, just because you ended there, thats up to the user. But then I would still expect to open the chat in the editor so that the experience is consistent.

At the same time, ideally all sessions opened from within the sidebar open in the sidebar. This is something we can currently not do for background/cloud chats, but should be able to do so in the future.

The chat is in the view because the user put it there- I just don't really get why not allow them to continue it there? That's not unpredictable to me, it would be unpredictable to move my chat in some other new location. From an API perspective, it would make sense to me to move the chat to the requested editor group unless `revealIfOpened` is set. But I don't think we should open a chat in a second view by default because I don't think I would ever need my window to look like this?

I guess I'm not thinking of the sessions view as like a file explorer, more like tabs that show my various running agents in different places. If I click one that is open in a view I expect it to reveal the view, not move them around.

I think it's up to you how it works though- if the change to openSession that I described makes sense, I could make it work that way. Or do you think we should leave the chat in the original location and also open a second instance?

And if we want to just open a second copy, then we should clean up the things that are weird about this right now (mainly the chat input kept in sync between the two copies) although it works fine afaik, it's just cosmetic.
Ok lets wait for more real usage feedback on this one before making a decision.
I found another case which does not work well and suggest we continue in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/280128

prs.title: Ensure Prompt variables are rendered correctly in contributed Chat Sessions history items
prs.author: DonJayamanne

comments.body:
The `name` field should be set to `ref.name` instead of `ref.id`. The `ref.name` field contains the formatted name (e.g., `prompt:filename.md`) that matches the expected pattern from `toPromptFileVariableEntry`, while `ref.id` contains the full identifier like `vscode.prompt.file__file:///path/to/file`. This is inconsistent with how prompt file variables are created in `toPromptFileVariableEntry` (line 388 in chatVariableEntries.ts) which uses `name: 'prompt:${basename(uri)}'`.
```suggestion
				name: ref.name,
```

The `isRoot` field is hardcoded to `false`, but according to `toPromptFileVariableEntry` (line 392 in chatVariableEntries.ts), prompt file variables with kind `PromptFile` should have `isRoot: true`. The correct value should be: `isRoot: kind !== PromptFileVariableKind.InstructionReference`. However, since this code only checks for `PromptFile` kind (line 416), it should use `isRoot: true` here.
```suggestion
				isRoot: true,
```

Consider adding test coverage for the new prompt file variable handling logic in `convertReferenceToVariable`. The test should verify that when a ChatPromptReference with a prompt file is converted back to an IChatRequestVariableEntry, the fields (especially `id`, `name`, `kind`, `isRoot`, etc.) are correctly set and match the expected IPromptFileVariableEntry structure. This would help prevent regressions and ensure the conversion logic works correctly for chat session history items.

prs.title: Fix Notebook cell scroll when cell is larger than viewport
prs.author: DonJayamanne

comments.body:
The comment references "options 3 & 4" which doesn't provide meaningful context. Consider replacing with a descriptive comment such as: "Track pointer-down state to prevent scroll and layout changes during text selection".
```suggestion
				// Track pointer-down state to prevent scroll and layout changes during text selection
```

The comment references "Option 3" which doesn't provide meaningful context. Consider replacing with a descriptive comment such as: "Defer scroll position updates while user is selecting text to prevent interrupting the selection".
```suggestion
			// Defer programmatic scrollTop changes while user is actively dragging a selection to prevent interrupting the selection process
```

[nitpick] Consider adding a JSDoc comment for the `_pointerDown` field explaining its purpose, such as: `/** Tracks pointer-down state to prevent scroll position changes during text selection */`. This would help future maintainers understand the field's purpose.
```suggestion
	private _initialized: boolean = false;
	/**
	 * Tracks pointer-down state to prevent scroll position changes during text selection.
	 */
```

[nitpick] The window-level `mouseup` event listener is registered inside the `registerMouseListener()` method, which is called during cell initialization. However, this creates a potential resource leak: when the CodeCell is disposed, the window-level listener will not be automatically cleaned up because it's attached to the window object, not the cell's DOM node.

The listener is registered with `this._register()`, which should handle disposal properly when the CodeCell instance is disposed. However, there's a subtle issue: if multiple cells are created and disposed rapidly (e.g., during scrolling in a large notebook), each cell creates a new window-level listener. While these are disposable, they remain active until the cell is explicitly disposed.

Consider adding a comment to clarify that the disposal is handled automatically via `this._register()`, or verify that this pattern follows the codebase conventions for window-level event listeners.

The comment references "Option 4" which suggests this was part of an experimental approach with numbered alternatives. This doesn't provide meaningful context for future maintainers. Consider replacing with a descriptive comment that explains *why* this behavior is needed, such as: "Prevent scroll event handling during drag selection to avoid interrupting the user's selection gesture".
```suggestion
				// Prevent scroll event handling during drag selection to avoid interrupting the user's selection gesture
```

comments.body:
## ðŸ“¬ CODENOTIFY

The following users are being notified based on files changed in this PR:

### @bpasero

Matched files:
- `src/vs/base/browser/markdownRenderer.ts`

Potential runtime error: `description` could be `undefined` when both `pastTenseMessage` and `invocationMessage` are undefined (line 883). Accessing `description.value` without checking if `description` exists will throw an error. 

Consider adding a null check:
```typescript
description = message ?? localize('chat.sessions.description.waitingForConfirmation', "Waiting for confirmation: {0}", typeof description === 'string' ? description : description?.value ?? '');
```
```suggestion
						description = message ?? localize('chat.sessions.description.waitingForConfirmation', "Waiting for confirmation: {0}", typeof description === 'string' ? description : description?.value ?? '');
```

The test suite in `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/test/browser/chatSessionsService.test.ts` is currently skipped (`suite.skip`) and tests the old `extractFileNameFromLink` method which has been replaced by `cleanUpProgress`. The tests should be updated to:
1. Remove the `.skip` to re-enable the suite
2. Update to test the new `cleanUpProgress` method
3. Add test cases for the new tick removal functionality (`/`+/g` regex)
4. Update test assertions to match the new behavior
We have a `renderAsPlaintext` helper that can strip out markdown syntax. Maybe what you are looking for here too?
You can also use `marked.lexer` to parse the string and find links in a more reliable way
@mjbvz using the string doesn't strip out the markdown link syntax and using the markdown just remove the link altogether :/

@mjbvz the issue here is that we want to display part of the link so that we indicate which file is being modified. That helper seems to be stripping out the link completely if the hyperlink doesn't have a text like `[]`

The empty link seems very fishy to me but if you can't change the markdown itself, look at how `renderAsPlaintext` works. You need to override the link renderer. The `includeCodeBlocksFences` option shows one example of this
However I'd look at why you have an empty link. That really would be invisible to the user if rendered directly as html
This is the response coming from github.com tool invocation, we don't have much control over it but I just added the new renderer to handle this cases
This should use `basename` to get the file name
Using the API it would be surprising you can't set both `includeCodeBlocksFences` and `preserveFileLinks` can be set. Can we make it so both can be enabled?
Instead of something so specific, could this be  a `linkFormatter` that takes the text and href and returns the text to display? That way the caller can handle all the file uri / chat specific logic
Is this still needed after adopting `renderAsPlaintext`?
You should be able to pass strings to `renderAsPlaintext` which will return them directly so you don't need this conditional
Where is the progress markdown string coming from? Could we update whatever is generating it to have better text for the link instead of using the href?

Could we update whoever generates `progress` to make sure it always a `MarkdownString`?
This is the model title, will fix that separately

Make sure to wrap this in a try catch in case it's not a valid URI. In those cases you could still try using `basename` from `path.ts` instead of our uri based one

Good idea, changed it

prs.title: Eliminate IChatAgentRequest.sessionId
prs.author: roblourens

comments.body:
The non-null assertion operator (`!`) on `parseLocalSessionId()` is unsafe. This function returns `string | undefined` when the URI scheme is not a local chat session. Since `sessionResource` can be any URI from different chat session providers (not just local sessions), this could cause a runtime error where `sessionId` becomes `undefined`, breaking code that expects a string.

Consider using a fallback or proper handling:
```typescript
const sessionId = LocalChatSessionUri.parseLocalSessionId(request.sessionResource) ?? request.sessionResource.toString();
```

Or validate that the session is local before parsing, similar to how it's done in other places in the codebase.
```suggestion
		const sessionId = LocalChatSessionUri.parseLocalSessionId(request.sessionResource) ?? request.sessionResource.toString();
```

prs.title: Add folder contribution points for chat agents/prompts/instructions
prs.author: pwang347

comments.body:
The async folder scanning operation is fire-and-forget, which can lead to race conditions. If the extension is removed before the async operation completes, the files could still be registered. Additionally, there's no tracking of the ongoing async operation, so it can't be properly cancelled.

Consider storing a disposable or promise for the async operation so it can be cancelled when the extension is removed. Alternatively, check if the extension is still valid before registering files inside the async callback.

The removal logic uses string matching (`includes('/${raw.path}/')`) which is fragile and can cause incorrect matches. For example, if one folder is named "test" and another is "test2", removing "test" would also remove files from "test2".

The key function at line 144 creates keys with the format `${extensionId}/${type}/${name}`, but folder-registered files have uniqueName = `${extensionId}/${path}/${name}` (line 272). This creates an inconsistency where the key becomes `${extensionId}/${type}/${extensionId}/${path}/${name}`, making the removal logic even more unreliable.

Consider creating a more structured approach to tracking folder-based registrations, or ensure the key format is consistent and use exact string matching or a dedicated data structure to track which files came from which folder.

The hardcoded description "Contributed from folder: ..." is not localized, unlike other user-facing messages in this file. Consider using the localize function to make this message translatable, consistent with the file's existing pattern (e.g., lines 238, 249, 259, etc.).
```suggestion
											const description = localize('extension.folder.file.description', "Contributed from folder: {0}", raw.path);
```

comments.body: @microsoft-github-policy-service agree

This test verifies that a file name search is cancelled when a new file name search is started, but the test doesn't actually verify the cancellation behavior. The test waits for both searches to complete and only includes a comment stating what should be verified. Consider using a mock or spy to verify that the cancellation token's `cancel()` method was called on the first search, or check that the first search throws a `CancellationError`.

The `stubModelService` function is duplicated three times in this file (lines 570, 713, and 823). This duplication increases maintenance burden. Consider extracting this function to `searchTestCommon.ts` where similar helper functions like `stubNotebookEditorService` are located, and reusing it across all test suites.

The nested ternary operator for determining `cancelledForNewSearch` reduces code readability. Consider refactoring this into an if-else chain or extracting it to a helper function that takes `ai` and `fileName` parameters and returns the appropriate cancellation flag.

The CSS class name `filenamematch` is inconsistent with the naming convention used elsewhere in this file. Other similar classes use camelCase with word separators (e.g., `.foldermatch` on line 226, `.filematch` on line 330). However, "filename" is typically two words. Consider changing this to `.fileNameMatch` or `.file-name-match` to be more explicit and consistent with the pattern used for multi-word concepts elsewhere in the codebase.
```suggestion
		const fileNameMatchElement = DOM.append(container, DOM.$('.fileNameMatch'));
```

When plain text search results are empty but file name results exist, this logic will show the file name results as a separate heading. However, if AI results also exist, the condition on line 2598 (`ret.length === 0 && !hasFileNameResults`) will be false, so plain text results won't be shown via `createTextSearchResultIterator`. This inconsistency could lead to different UI structures depending on whether AI results are present. Consider handling the case where only file name results exist more explicitly.

The `stubNotebookEditorService` function is duplicated three times in this file (lines 582, 723, and 833). This duplication increases maintenance burden. This function already exists in `searchTestCommon.ts` and should be imported and reused instead of being duplicated.

prs.title: Implements InlineCompletion.jumpToPosition
prs.author: hediet

comments.body: Red CI

The `jumpToPosition` property lacks JSDoc documentation explaining what it does, when it should be used, and how it interacts with other properties like `insertText`. For consistency with other properties in this interface, it should have proper documentation.
```suggestion

	/**
	 * The position where the cursor should be placed after the completion is applied.
	 * If not set, the cursor will be placed at the end of the inserted text.
	 * This can be used to move the cursor to a specific location, for example,
	 * inside a snippet or after a particular character.
	 * If used in conjunction with `insertText`, the position should be within the replaced range.
	 */
```

The text "Jump to" should use title-style capitalization for consistency with VS Code UI labels. According to the coding guidelines, command labels and UI elements should use title-style capitalization with each word capitalized.
```suggestion
							content: `Jump To`,
```

The `clip-path` polygon appears to be creating a triangle/arrow shape but has a duplicate point (`8px 0` appears twice) which is unnecessary. The polygon should be `polygon(8px 0, 0 50%, 8px 100%)` without the duplicate final point, as polygons automatically close.
```suggestion
		clip-path: polygon(8px 0, 0 50%, 8px 100%);
```

prs.title: Do more word definition checks to return early
