comments.body: The `wordDefinition` RegExp may have the global flag set, which means `exec()` maintains state via `lastIndex`. Not resetting `lastIndex` before each call can cause `exec()` to skip matches or fail unexpectedly. Add `wordDefinition.lastIndex = 0;` before this `exec()` call to match the established pattern in the codebase.

This word definition validation logic is duplicated at lines 103-108, 115-120, 173-178, and 180-185. Consider extracting this into a helper function like `isValidWord(text: string, wordDefinition: RegExp): boolean` to improve maintainability and reduce code duplication.

The established pattern in this codebase is to reset `lastIndex = 0` before calling `exec()` on a regex (see `src/vs/editor/common/core/wordHelper.ts:73,157` and `src/vs/editor/common/services/textModelSync/textModelSync.impl.ts:298`). prs.title: debt - Make `ServicesAccessor#get` honor throwIfStrict and remove `getIfExists`
prs.author: jrieken

comments.body:
The `get` method can now return `undefined` when a service is not found and the instantiation service is not in strict mode, but the return type is still `T` (non-nullable). After calling `_throwIfStrict` on line 104, if the service is not in strict mode, the method continues and returns `result` which is `undefined`. This creates a type safety issue.

Consider either:
1. Updating the return type of `ServicesAccessor.get` to `T | undefined` to reflect the actual behavior, or
2. Always throwing an error when a service is not found (which would be a breaking change), or
3. Returning a default/null object instead of undefined when not in strict mode

prs.title: agent sessions - some fixes when shown in chat view
prs.author: bpasero

comments.body:
There's a potential conflict between two visibility controls operating on the same element:

1. `updateSessionsControlVisibility()` (line 319) sets visibility based on configuration and widget state
2. The `notifyResults` callback (line 281) sets visibility based on filtered session count

Since both operate on `sessionsContainer`, they can override each other, potentially causing the container to be shown even when there are no sessions to display. 

Consider one of these solutions:
- Have `updateSessionsControlVisibility()` check the current session count before setting visibility
- Make `notifyResults` control visibility of an inner element (e.g., the sessions list itself) rather than the outer container
- Add logic to ensure both conditions (configuration enabled AND sessions available) must be true for the container to be visible

This blank line appears to be unintentional and should be removed to maintain consistent formatting.
```suggestion

```

prs.title: Submit Contributed Sessions requetsts using ChatWidget
prs.author: DonJayamanne

comments.body:
Race condition: The chat widget may not have its `viewModel` initialized immediately after `openEditor` returns. The `getWidgetBySessionResource` method checks `w.viewModel?.sessionResource`, but the viewModel is only set asynchronously in the editor's `setInput` method after resolving the editor model.

This means that `chatWidget` will likely be `undefined` and the prompt/attachedContext will be silently ignored instead of being sent.

Consider one of these solutions:
1. Wait for the widget's viewModel to be set (e.g., by listening to `onDidChangeViewModel`)
2. Use `chatWidgetService.onDidAddWidget` to wait for the widget registration
3. Use the `openSession` method from `IChatWidgetService` instead of `editorService.openEditor`, which properly returns the widget
4. Add error logging when the widget is not found but a prompt was provided

The old implementation using `chatService.sendRequest` would have thrown an error if the session wasn't found, making failures explicit.

See below

prs.title: Add performance markers to inline completions
prs.author: benibenj

comments.body: Red CI too

Performance markers are lost when `withRename()` creates a new `InlineSuggestData` instance. The `withRename()` method creates a new `InlineSuggestData` but doesn't copy the `performance` field, causing all previously collected performance markers to be discarded. This means items that go through rename processing will lose markers like 'providerReturned', 'itemCreated', 'providersResolved', etc. The `withRename()` method should preserve the performance tracking data by passing or copying the existing `performance` object to the new instance.

Performance markers are being added to `providerSuggestions` after `proposeRenameRefactoring` returns new items in the `suggestions` array. At line 275, markers are added to items in `providerSuggestions`, but `proposeRenameRefactoring` may return new `InlineSuggestionItem` instances (via `InlineSuggestionItem.create(suggestItem.withRename(...))`) when rename is possible. This means the 'renameProcessed' marker is added to the wrong items and won't appear in telemetry. The marker should be added to the items in the `suggestions` array instead.
```suggestion
				suggestions.forEach(s => s.addPerformanceMarker('renameProcessed'));
```

The 'minShowDelayPassed' performance marker is being added to `providerSuggestions` instead of `suggestions`. Since `suggestions` may contain different items than `providerSuggestions` after rename processing (line 271-273), this marker will be added to the wrong items and won't appear in telemetry for items that went through rename. The marker should be added to the items in the `suggestions` array.
```suggestion
				suggestions.forEach(s => s.addPerformanceMarker('minShowDelayPassed'));
```

This looks a lot like the `performance.mark` API so I was confused at first FYI:

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/643ae5a99809dd34ae1c69d0bbbab34b9a0a2bc3/src/vs/base/common/performance.ts#L43-L51

Consider changing the name to differentiate it a little?

prs.author: deepak1556

comments.body:
The content tracing window bypasses the `ready-to-show` event that `openChildWindow` uses (line 1056) by calling `show()` in the `did-finish-load` handler instead. While this might be intentional to execute JavaScript before showing, it creates inconsistency with the window display pattern. The `paintWhenInitiallyHidden: false` option passed to `openChildWindow` may conflict with this approach.

Consider either:
1. Using the standard `ready-to-show` event and executing JavaScript before that event fires
2. Documenting why the different approach is necessary for the content tracing window

The use of `executeJavaScript` to mock `window.prompt` should include a comment explaining the security implications or why it's safe in this context. Since this is injecting code into a `chrome://` URL (which is Chromium's internal UI), it's relatively safe, but this should be documented to prevent future confusion or accidental misuse of this pattern in less secure contexts.

prs.title: Use toPromptFileVariableEntry to create prompt file variable
prs.author: DonJayamanne

comments.body:
Using `toPromptFileVariableEntry` with `automaticallyAdded: true` causes the attachment to be hidden from the UI. In `chatAttachmentsContentPart.ts` (lines 132-136), prompt file entries with `automaticallyAdded: true` are skipped during rendering. Additionally, these entries are filtered out when editing requests (see `chatWidget.ts` line 1495).

The old code created a regular file attachment (kind: 'file'), but the new code creates a prompt file entry (kind: 'promptFile') which is semantically intended for prompt instructions files, not regular code files. For regular file attachments, consider using `toFileVariableEntry(uri)` instead, which creates an `IChatRequestFileEntry` and matches the original behavior.

prs.title: Add GitHub Actions workflow for NodeJS with Gulp
prs.author: JaclynCodes

comments.body: @copilot open a new pull request to apply changes based on the comments in [this thread](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/279278#pullrequestreview-3503248156)

The workflow is missing node_modules caching, which is used in all VS Code workflows to speed up builds. Consider implementing the caching pattern used in other workflows (e.g., `.github/workflows/pr.yml` lines 31-73) that uses a computed cache key and tar archives for efficient caching.
```suggestion
    # Cache node_modules using tar archive and computed key
    - name: Restore node_modules cache
      id: node_modules-cache
      uses: actions/cache@v4
      with:
        path: node_modules.tar
        key: ${{ runner.os }}-node${{ matrix.node-version }}-modules-${{ hashFiles('package-lock.json') }}
        restore-keys: |
          ${{ runner.os }}-node${{ matrix.node-version }}-modules-

    - name: Extract node_modules from cache
      if: steps.node_modules-cache.outputs.cache-hit == 'true'
      run: |
        tar -xf node_modules.tar

    - name: Install dependencies
      if: steps.node_modules-cache.outputs.cache-hit != 'true'
      run: |
        npm install
        tar -cf

[nitpick] The workflow uses `ubuntu-latest` but existing VS Code workflows use self-hosted runners with specific pools (e.g., `[ self-hosted, 1ES.Pool=1es-vscode-oss-ubuntu-22.04-x64 ]`). While `ubuntu-latest` may work for testing purposes, consider whether this workflow should align with the existing CI infrastructure or if it serves a different purpose that justifies using GitHub-hosted runners.
```suggestion
    runs-on: [ self-hosted, 1ES.Pool=1es-vscode-oss-ubuntu-22.04-x64 ]
```

The workflow should use `node-version-file: .nvmrc` instead of a version matrix. All existing VS Code workflows use the .nvmrc file to ensure consistency with the project's Node.js version (currently 22.20.0). Testing multiple Node versions is not necessary here and doesn't align with the project's testing patterns.
```suggestion
    steps:
    - uses: actions/checkout@v4

    - name: Use Node.js version from .nvmrc
      uses: actions/setup-node@v4
      with:
        node-version-file: .nvmrc
```

Use `npm ci` instead of `npm install`. All VS Code CI workflows use `npm ci` to ensure reproducible builds by installing exact versions from package-lock.json, which is critical for CI environments.
```suggestion
        npm ci
```

Missing `permissions: {}` declaration. VS Code workflows explicitly set permissions to follow the principle of least privilege for security. This should be added after the workflow name and triggers.
```suggestion

permissions: {}
```

The workflow is missing the Microsoft copyright header. All VS Code files, including workflow files, must include the standard copyright header at the top:
```yaml
# /*---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#  *  Copyright (c) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved.
#  *  Licensed under the MIT License. See License.txt in the project root for license information.
#  *--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------*/
```

Running bare `gulp` works (it executes the default 'compile' task), but VS Code typically invokes gulp through npm scripts with specific memory settings: `npm run gulp <task>` or `node --max-old-space-size=8192 ./node_modules/gulp/bin/gulp.js <task>`. Consider using the npm script approach for consistency with the rest of the codebase.
```suggestion
        npm run gulp
```

The workflow is missing concurrency control. VS Code workflows include concurrency settings to cancel in-progress runs when new commits are pushed, which saves CI resources. Add a concurrency section like:
```yaml
concurrency:
  group: ${{ github.workflow }}-${{ github.ref }}
  cancel-in-progress: true
```

The workflow is using outdated action versions. VS Code's existing workflows use `actions/checkout@v5` and `actions/setup-node@v6`. Please update to match the repository standards.
```suggestion
    - uses: actions/checkout@v5

    - name: Use Node.js ${{ matrix.node-version }}
      uses: actions/setup-node@v6
```

There are two issues with this line:

1. **Incorrect observable access**: Using `.get()` on the `cursorAtInlineEdit` observable doesn't establish a reactive dependency. Within this derived callback, you should use `.read(reader)` to properly track the observable.

2. **Incorrect logic**: The OR logic means if the cursor is at the inline edit location, the showRange check is bypassed. The showRange should be an additional constraint. When showRange is specified, the cursor must be within it regardless of other conditions.

The correct implementation should be:
```typescript
const cursorInsideShowRange = (inlineEditResult.showRange?.containsPosition(cursorPos) ?? true);
```

The `cursorAtInlineEdit` check is already implicitly handled by the `cursorPos` being used in the position check, and the explicit check appears on line 630 for a different purpose (to include in the return value).

			const cursorInsideShowRange = (inlineEditResult.showRange?.containsPosition(cursorPos)

prs.title: Hide more instances of Keep/Undo for non-local chat sessions
prs.author: DonJayamanne

comments.body:
The approach used here differs from the one in `chatEditingActions.ts`. In this file, the code checks `isLocalChat` (whether the session is a local session), while in `chatEditingActions.ts`, it checks `ChatContextKeys.lockedToCodingAgent.negate()` (whether the session is NOT locked to coding agent).

These two conditions are not semantically equivalent. According to the code in `chatEditor.ts` (lines 209-225), a non-local session may or may not be locked to the coding agent depending on whether a contribution is found. This means:
- A local session: `isLocalChat = true`, `lockedToCodingAgent = false`
- A non-local session with contribution: `isLocalChat = false`, `lockedToCodingAgent = true`
- A non-local session without contribution: `isLocalChat = false`, `lockedToCodingAgent = false`

For the third case, the overlay widget would be hidden (because `isLocalChat` is false), but the Keep/Undo actions would still be shown (because `lockedToCodingAgent` is false). This creates an incons

The return value here is of type `string | undefined`. The function `parseLocalSessionId` returns the session ID string if it's a local session, or `undefined` if it's not. While this works as a boolean expression (truthy string vs falsy undefined), it would be clearer and more semantically correct to convert it to an explicit boolean:

```typescript
return !!LocalChatSessionUri.parseLocalSessionId(chatModel.sessionResource);
```

or

```typescript
return LocalChatSessionUri.parseLocalSessionId(chatModel.sessionResource) !== undefined;
```

This makes the intent explicit and ensures the derived observable has a consistent `boolean` type rather than `string | undefined`.
```suggestion
			return !!LocalChatSessionUri.parseLocalSessionId(chatModel.sessionResource);
```

## ðŸ“¬ CODENOTIFY

### @jrieken

Matched files:
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatEditing/chatEditingCheckpointTimeline.ts`
- `src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatEditing/chatEditingCheckpointTimelineImpl.ts`

Debug `console.log` statement should be removed before merging. This appears to be temporary debugging code that was left in.

Every call to `getDiffsForFilesInSession()` creates a new set of derived observables and a new `prevDiffs` cache map that will never be cleaned up, potentially causing a memory leak. Consider caching the result as an instance variable (similar to how `canUndo` and `canRedo` are cached) and creating the observable only once when the instance is constructed.

prs.title: Fix code block rendering logic to prevent unnecessary re-renders. Fix #277574
prs.author: tamuratak

comments.body:
The logic change appears to introduce a bug. When `other.content.value === this.markdown.content.value` (identical content) AND there ARE codeblocks (`lastCodeblock` is truthy), the method will no longer return `true` early. Instead, it will proceed to check the streaming edit condition. If that condition is false (e.g., the codeblock is complete or doesn't have a codemapperUri), the method returns `false`, indicating the content has changed when it actually hasn't. This will cause unnecessary re-renders.

The original logic correctly returned `true` for any case where content values were equal. The new condition `&& !lastCodeblock` restricts this to only cases without codeblocks. Consider these scenarios:
1. Content is identical, no codeblocks: Returns `true` âœ“
2. Content is identical, has completed codeblocks: Falls through, returns `false` âœ— (should be `true`)
3. Content is identical, has streaming edit codeblock: May return `true` via second check âœ“

A better fix might be to check

I'm kind of confused why this is necessary. If the markdown contents are identical between parts then there should be no need to re-render--you should get the same output each time. If a code block is not rendering correctly then I think that may be an underlying bug with how the block is rendered

When a session is loaded, it can happen that the Markdown is identical but the code blocks havenâ€™t been rendered yet. The `hasSameContent` function is being used to check whether code block rendering is complete. Thatâ€™s why I believe the correct fix is to update `hasSameContent`.

I havenâ€™t traced the session-loading implementation in detail, though.

Below is the response I received when I asked gpt-5.1-codex to investigate.


---

- `ChatMarkdownContentPart.hasSameContent()` short-circuits purely on markdown string equality [chatMarkdownContentPart.ts#L415-L430](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/main/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatContentParts/chatMarkdownContentPart.ts#L415-L430). When you reopen an older session, the list already holds stale `ChatMarkdownContentPart` instances for those response IDs, but their DOM was cleared when the template was recycled (`clearRenderedParts` disposes and empties nodes when the template is reassigned) [chatListRenderer.

> When you reopen an older session, the list already holds stale ChatMarkdownContentPart instances for those response IDs

Not sure the the model is correct here. The list view is used to render whatever the current session is. Its contents get replaced when you switch models and there should be no 'stale' components around anywhere.

Are you still reproducing this with the same steps from https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/277574#issue-3627720123? I don't seem to hit that on current Insiders.

I can reproduce the issue. steps: 1. Start a new chat. 2. Type the prompt. 3. Move the session to the editor area. 4. Close the chat in the editor area. 5. Restore the session in the chat. Version: 1.107.0-insider (Universal) Commit: 6e0893efb3d4b50c43dcff8979c722e6019de61d Date: 2025-12-02T05:02:35.190Z Electron: 39.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12869810 Chromium: 142.0.7444.175 Node.js: 22.21.1 V8: 14.2.231.21-electron.0 OS: Darwin arm64 24.6.0 Name: GitHub Copilot Chat Id: GitHub.copilot-chat Description: AI chat features powered by Copilot Version: 0.34.2025120202 Publisher: GitHub VS Marketplace Link: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.copilot-chat settings: ``` "github.copilot.chat.summarizeAgentConversationHistory.enabled": false, "github.copilot.chat.useResponsesApi": true, "gith
I opened a new PR for an alternative fix. #281505. You might prefer it.

prs.title: Resolve regression where build task did not start in wsl
prs.author: anthonykim1

comments.body:
Testing result:

| VS Code Context | Workspace State | Terminal Type | Expected Behavior | Actual Behavior (manual testing by Me) |
|-----------------|-----------------|---------------|-----------------------------|---------------------|
| Local           | Trusted |  Local |  âœ… Terminal opens |  âœ… Terminal opens
| Local          | Untrusted       | Local         | âŒ Terminal blocked |  âŒ Terminal blocked
| Local          | Empty           | Local         | âœ… Terminal opens |  âŒ Terminal blocked until I `trust folder & continue` in the modal dialog
| Remote         | Trusted         | Remote        | âœ… Terminal opens |   âœ… Terminal opens
| Remote         | Untrusted       | Remote  + local from remote      | âœ… Terminal opens | ~âŒ Terminal blocked for both `remote&local` terminal.~ https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/commit/355a6375f57e56f1a3cee07e075e6378512706d7 and [2c40314](https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/pull/279249/commits/2c403146ea7d6383f71394f1d4a34101aa584c7a) fixe

Using `JSON.stringify(this._shellLaunchConfig)` may expose sensitive information in logs. The `IShellLaunchConfig` interface contains:
- `env`: environment variables that could include secrets, tokens, or API keys
- `args`: command-line arguments that could contain sensitive data
- `shellIntegrationNonce`: security-related nonces

Consider logging only specific non-sensitive fields needed for debugging, or implement a custom sanitization function that redacts sensitive properties before stringifying.

Based on the screenshot in https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/275011, I would have expected this to reproduce in a non-empty workspace in which case it would trigger `_onProcessExit` based purely on `trusted`?

Ahhh The activeWorkspaceUri was undefined for wsl (for both task and regular terminal it seems like)

I might have to debug why `const activeWorkspaceRootUri = this._historyService.getLastActiveWorkspaceRoot(Schemas.file);` is undefined now
